19971210_005.e: Residential care homes for elderly
Following is a question by the Hon Lau Kong-wah and a reply by the Secretary for Health and Welfare, Mrs Katherine Fok, in the Provisional Legislative Council today (Wednesday):
Question:

Currently, the waiting time for admission to subsidised residential care homes for elderly persons is exceedingly long and many elderly persons pass away before residential care places can be allocated to them.
In this connection, will the Government inform this Council:

(a) whether it will consider subsidising more private residential care homes for elderly persons, so as to increase the number of residential care places; if so, of the number of places to be increased in each of the coming five years, and of the waiting time that can be shortened as a result of such increases; and
(b) of the criteria currently adopted by the authority in determining the eligibility and priority of elderly persons for allocation of places in subvented residential care homes?
Reply:
Madam President,
(a) Through the "Bought Place Scheme", the Government has bought a total of 1,200 places from private homes for the elderly since 1989.
To enhance the Scheme, we will purchase an additional 2,400 places in the coming three years.
Apart from buying places from private homes for the elderly, we will also provide some 6,000 places in subvented and self-financing homes in the coming four years.
Additional residential care places will bring immediate benefit to applicants who are on the top of the current waiting list.
However, waiting time is affected by a lot of factors.

Apart from the supply of places, the increase of new applicants, its rate of increase, preferences indicated by applicants as to location of residential care homes, their parent organisations and choice of meals provided, will influence the waiting time of individual applicants.
For the time being, we are not in a position to make an accurate assessment if the increase of residential care places can result in the shortening of the overall waiting time.
(b) Different types of residential care homes have different admission criteria.
Generally speaking, the health condition and family status of an applicant will be considered.

For instance, for the elderly who apply for admission to Homes for the Aged, they should need assistance in daily living activities such as shopping and cooking, but they, for various reasons, cannot turn to family members for help.
For those who apply for admission to Care-and-attention Homes, they usually suffer from some functional disabilities and need assistance with personal care, such as bathing.
At present, the priority for admission to homes for the elderly will be determined in accordance with the date of application of an applicant.
For applicants who are in urgent need, immediate placement can be arranged without adhering to the normal waiting procedure.
19980512_015.e: Ad Hoc Committee to discuss residential care for the elderly
The Ad Hoc Committee on Housing and Residential Care of the Elderly Commission will meet this Thursday (May 14) to discuss the participation of the private sector in the provision of elderly homes.
The meeting, chaired by Mr Moses Cheng, will also discuss the housing needs for the elderly, the Bought Place Scheme and the review on the admission criteria for residential care services.
19980527_016.e: Elderly Commission to discuss residential care for elderly
The Elderly Commission will meet tomorrow (Thursday) to discuss the Consultancy Report on the Needs of Elderly People on Hong Kong for Residential Care and Community Support Services.
The meeting will also discuss the Bought Place Scheme, the review of care services for elderly living in the community and the progress report of the health services for the elderly.
19980715_019.e: LCQ4:Govt to study community care services for the elderly
The following is a question by the Hon Leung Yiu-chung and a reply by the Secretary for Health and Welfare, Mrs Katherine Fok, in the Legislative Council today (Wednesday):
Question:
As quite a large number of elderly persons are waiting for places in various kinds of subvented homes for the elderly, will the Government inform this Council:
(a) of the respective numbers of eligible elderly persons who are currently on the waiting lists for places in care and attention homes, homes for the elderly and hostels for the elderly;

(b) whether it has assessed the amount of additional financial and manpower resources required every year in order to help the elderly persons in need to be admitted immediately to relevant homes for the elderly; if so, what the results are;
(c) whether it has plans to allocate additional resources so that the elderly persons in need can be admitted to relevant homes within a short period of time; and
(d) of its comprehensive plan to shorten the waiting time for places in subvented homes for the elderly?
Reply:
Madam President,

As at the end of June 1998, the number of elderly persons on the waiting list for subsidised care and attention homes, homes for the aged and hostels for the elderly were about 19 000, 7 000 and 290 respectively.

In view of the large number of elderly persons waiting for places in care and attention homes, we have carried out a survey on the eligibility of the elderly persons on the waiting list for these homes.
The findings show that about 10 500 elderly persons (55%) meet the existing eligibility criteria for admission to care and attention homes.

In consideration of the huge demand of the elderly for services of care and attention homes, the Government pledged, in the Policy Address last year, to allocate substantial resources to increase the supply of residential care places.
An additional 3 300 places in subvented residential care homes and 1 400 places in subvented nursing homes will be provided between 1998 and 2002.
Besides, the number of bought places in private residential care homes will be increased by 2 400 from 1998 to 2001.
The capital expenditure of the first two programmes will amount to several billion dollars.

Upon the full implementation of the three programmes, the Government's annual recurrent expenditure on residential care services will go up from $1 billion last year to $1.7 billion, and the number of additional staff needed will be around 3 000.
In addition to the aforesaid programmes, we are further examining various short-term or longer-term measures.

For example, the Social Welfare Department is now liaising with residential care homes on enhancing the utilization rate of the existing places, beyond the present 95%, with a view to increasing the supply of places within a short period of time.
Recently, we have announced a programme to purchase, at higher prices, 2 400 additional places from private residential care homes within the next three years.
We will closely monitor the market response.
If the response is favourable and if resources also permit, we will consider increasing the number of places to be bought beyond 2 400 places.
In the meantime, we are conducting an assessment on the demand of elderly people on services of care and attention homes, and mapping out a strategy to address the shortfall of places.

Apart from increasing the number of residential care places, we will also review the existing referral, assessment and allocation arrangements for residential care services to ensure that the limited resources available will be targetted at elderly persons with genuine need.

On the other hand, it has always been the Government's policy to encourage the elderly to live at their home, until such time when their health has deteriorated and their care needs can be met neither by their families nor by community care, residential care services will be arranged for them.
In this connection, we are exploring means of improving domiciliary and community care services to enable the majority of elderly persons to remain at home.

Lastly, I would like to reiterate that whenever an elderly person has an urgent need to be admitted to a residential care home in a short time, special arrangement can be made by the Social Welfare Department to arrange placements, the waiting time of which will be reduced substantially to several months.
19991014_035.e: Government committed to improve elderly, welfare services

The Government has secured the co-operation of the Housing Authority, the Land Development Corporation, MTRC and KCRC to provide premises for more than 14,000 residential care places in the coming nine years.

For the short term, the Government expects to provide an additional 4,500 residential care places of various types between 1999/2000 and 2001/2002 to shorten the waiting time for admission into care-and-attention homes.

At the same time, the Government will allocate $10 million over the next two years to help strengthen the functioning and problem-solving abilities of families at risk and the development of parenting skills.
These were disclosed by the Secretary for Health and Welfare, Dr E K Yeoh, at the LegCo Welfare Services Panel meeting on the 1999 Policy Address today (Thursday).
Speaking of work progress, Dr Yeoh said of the 38 pledges made last year to improve elderly services, action on 11 pledges had been completed while the rest were making steady progress.

Main achievements in the past year include the commissioning of over 3,500 subsidized residential care places for the elderly; shortening the waiting time for care-and-attention places to an average of 18 months; launching of pilot schemes to provide dementia units at some care-and-attention homes and day care centres for the elderly; increasing the number of licensed private residential care homes from 41 to 242; and providing enhanced home care services to the elderly living at home.
We will conduct a comprehensive review so as to identify the best way to provide care and support services to the elderly living at home," Dr Yeoh said.

To enable elderly people to lead an active and meaningful life in their golden years, Dr Yeoh said the Social Welfare Department, Education Department and voluntary organizations had been providing them a range of continuing education courses, as well as social and recreational activities.
"Through social networking, we have recruited several thousand elderly people as volunteers to visit vulnerable elderly people.
"And building on the momentum of the International Year of Older Persons, we plan to strengthen our work in this key area in the coming years," he added.

Turning to other welfare services, Dr Yeoh noted that significant achievements had also been made in the past year, i.e. the introduction of a new Service Performance Monitoring System for SWD and all subvented NGOs; the publication of the Rehabilitation Programme Plan; and completion of the Review of the Community Rehabilitation Network.

Notwithstanding the present climate, Dr Yeoh continued, the Government will inject fund to provide in the next financial year new or additional services, including 300 child-care centre places, over 600 day and residential places for the disabled, seven child protection workers and 12 school social worker units.
"In conclusion," Dr Yeoh stressed, "the Government remains firmly committed to helping those members of our community in need."
20000405_014.e: LC Q14: Admission to subvented residential care homes for the elderly
Following is a question for the Hon Bernard Chan and a written reply by the Secretary for Health and Welfare, Dr E K Yeoh, in the Legislative Council today (April 5):
Question:

There are complaints that applicants for admission to subvented residential care homes for the elderly such as hostels, homes for the aged, care-and-attention homes and nursing homes, have to wait for a long time before such places are allocated to them.
In this connection, will the Government inform this Council of :
(a) the respective numbers of applicants for admission to various types of residential care homes who had died before places were allocated to them in the past five years;
(b) the current waiting time for admission to each type of residential care homes for the elderly; and
(c) the measures it will take to shorten such waiting time?
Reply:
Madam President,

(a) The number of applicants who passed away while on the waiting list for different residential care places is about seven, 350 and 2,500 per year in the past five years for self-care hostels, homes for the aged and care and attention homes respectively.
Social Welfare Department established six nursing homes in 1998 and the number of applicants who passed away while waiting for these homes in the past two years is about 800 per annum.
The death rate is influenced by biological, medical and other factors and should not be seen to relate directly to the waiting time.
(b) The waiting time for different applicants will vary due to their health conditions and specific preferences.
For those who are in urgent need, priority placement can be arranged within a few weeks, or even days, where emergency placement is justified.

On the other hand, applicants who have indicated locational, home, religious or diet preferences, their waiting time will usually be longer than those who have not indicated any particular preferences.

As at March 2000, on average, there was a waiting time of about five, 16, 22 and 12 months for application for places in self-care hostels, homes for the aged, care and attention homes and nursing homes respectively.
When interpreting the waiting time for residential care places, we should take note that not all applicants have an immediate need for residential care services.
Under the existing practice, applicants are not required to undergo care need assessments before registration on the waiting list.

Some of the elderly people on the waiting list (about 10%) are already receiving subsidized residential care services but are awaiting transfer to another residential care institution, providing a different level of care service.
(c) To shorten the waiting time for residential care, we are adopting a range of measures, as follows :
(i) According to a recent survey, only about 60% of the elderly people on the care-and-attention home waiting list are genuinely in need of residential care.

We will put in place an enhanced gatekeeping mechanism by the summer of 2000 to target subsidized residential care service to the frail elderly with genuine need so that their waiting time can be shortened.
(ii) The Social Welfare Department will be introducing a pilot project on continuum of care in residential care homes.
Residential care homes taking part in the pilot will be provided with additional resources to provide higher levels of care services for their frail elderly residents.
This will reduce the need for transfer of elderly residents between residential care homes providing different levels of care.

Overseas experience has also shown that upon implementation of the continuum of care funding formula, residential care homes are more inclined to admit frail elderly with higher levels of care needs, thereby reducing their waiting time for admission to residential care homes.

(iii) To accord with the wishes of the majority of our elderly population who prefer to be cared for at home, we will continue to expand and upgrade our home and community care services for the frail elderly.
In 2000-01, an additional $99 million has been earmarked to provide additional home and community care services in districts of high concentration of elderly population.
These services will provide an alternative to the frail elderly who might otherwise have to apply for admission to residential care homes.
(iv) In 2000/2001, a total of 2,510 additional residential care places will be provided to meet the residential care service need.

(v) We will continue to engage the private sector to encourage and facilitate them to provide quality residential care service to give more choices to families in the middle and higher income groups who are willing to pay for better quality services for their elderly members.
This will help target our elderly residential care programme at those who are in need of subsidized service, thereby reducing their waiting time.
END/Wednesday, April 5, 2000

20000428_029.e: A 44-year-old man arrested by Customs Drug Investigation Bureau will appear in Kwun Tong Magistracy this (April 28) afternoon, charged with trafficking in a dangerous drug and manufacturing a dangerous drug.
The suspect was arrested by the officers yesterday in Lam Tin following the seizure of 820 grams of No. 4 heroin worth about $500,000.
Shortly before 7 pm, officers of Customs Drug Investigation Bureau intercepted a man at Ping Tin Estate.
As a result, 120 grams of No. 4 heroin were reportedly found in his possession.
A subsequent search of the residence of the suspect resulted in the further seizure of 700 grams of No. 4 heroin and a set of heroin manufacturing apparatus.

"We believe that this drug syndicate has been operated for about a month and the drugs seized were mainly for distribution in East Kowloon area," said a spokesman for the Customs and Excise Department.
19991222_007.e: Seizure of No. 4 heroin by Customs

A 21-year-old man, arrested by Customs in connection with the seizure of $7 million worth of No. 4 heroin in Kwun Tong this (Wednesday) morning, will appear at Kwun Tong Magistracy tomorrow to face "Trafficking in Dangerous Drug" charge.

Following prolonged investigation, officers from Customs Drug Investigation Bureau mounted an anti-narcotics operation in the vicinity of a public carpark at the junction of Shun On Road and Shun Lee Tsuen Road, Kwun Tong at about 6:30 am today.
The officers swang into action when seeing their target, a 21-year-old man, acting suspiciously near a private car.
The suspect was arrested when trying to unload 15 slabs of No. 4 heroin, weighing 7 kilograms, from the boot of the vehicle.
"Enquiries revealed that the dangerous drugs were for distribution in Kowloon area," a spokesman for the Customs and Excise Department said.
The maximum penalty for the offence of "Trafficking in a dangerous drugs" is a fine of $5 million and life imprisonment, the spokesman warned.
19990330_028.e: Seizure of High Graded Heroin at Airport
Airport Customs officers yesterday (Monday) seized 7.5 kilograms of No. 4 heroin, worth $7.5 million, from two women from an incoming flight from Bangkok.
Shortly after 1 pm yesterday, the two women, both local residents, approached the Customs counter for clearance upon their arrival.
Their bulky and thick clothing, however, raised the suspicion of the Customs officers.
Upon subsequent personal search, the drugs, being packed into a number of packets strapped around the bodies, thigh and inside their shoes, were uncovered.
The arrested, aged 28 and 34, will appear at Tsuen Wan Magistracy tomorrow, to face charge of "trafficking in a dangerous drug" under the Dangerous Drugs Ordinance.
Customs officers have so far this year effected 10 drug trafficking cases at the airport.
A total of 20.8 kilograms of heroin, 8.2 kilograms of cannabis resin and 1.1 kilograms of cocaine were seized.
A total of 13 suspects, including seven Chinese men, two Chinese women and four foreigners, were arrested.
In most of the cases, the drugs were concealed by body-packed method, and uncovered after personal search.
Trafficking in a dangerous drug is a serious offence.
The maximum penalty is life imprisonment.
19990106_046.e: Seizure of No.4 Heroin at Airport
Watchfulness on the part of Customs officers led to the seizure of 6.1 kilograms of No. 4 heroin worth $6.1 million at the Airport yesterday (Tuesday).
Two men, aged 22 and 37, who were about to depart for Taiwan, were arrested in connection with the seizure.

Acting on intelligence, Customs officers of the Airport Investigation Division and Customs Drug Investigation Bureau yesterday morning conducted an anti-narcotics operation to process outgoing passengers at the departure level of the Airport.
During the operation, two Hong Kong residents, who were about to depart for Taiwan by an international flight, were intercepted for search.
As a result, each of them was found body-packed with 2.9 kilograms and 3.2 kilograms of high grade heroin respectively.
Customs officers conducted search of two residential premises at Tsuen Wan and Sha Tau Kok but no further seizure was made.
"This is the first major drug seizure made by Customs officers at the Airport this year," said a spokesman for the Customs and Excise Department.
Investigation into the case was still ongoing in order to track down other syndicate members, the spokesman added.
The two arrested will be separately charged with trafficking in a dangerous drug.
They will appear at Tsuen Wan Magistracy later today.
19991217_003.e: Police believed that a drug manufacturing centre has been neutralised following the arrest of a 39-year-old man and the seizure of $16 million of suspected No.4 heroin by officers attached to the Narcotics Bureau (NB) yesterday (Thursday).

Speaking at a press briefing this (Friday) afternoon, Chief Superintendent of Narcotics Bureau , Mr Koo Sii-hong, said following extensive investigation into a drug syndicate, NB officers laid an ambush outside a carpark at Lung Fung Garden in Sheung Shui yesterday afternoon.
"Police officers intercepted a private car at about 3.30 pm and seized about 14.7 kilograms of suspected No.4 heroin inside the boot.
The 39-year-old driver on board was arrested," he said.

"Subsequent search in a flat on Luk Ming Street in To Kwa Wan led to the seizure of another 200 grams of suspected No.4 heroin and a quantity of drug manufacturing equipment including hydraulic jacks as well as chemical for drug dilution."
"The haul, with a total weight of 15 kilograms, could fetch about $16 million in the retail market," he added.

Initial enquiries revealed that the drug manufacturing centre was linked to a drug syndicate neutralised by NB officers early this month during which $3.76 million worth of heroin and two genuine pistols were seized.
The man is still being detained for enquiries.
Mr Koo said that there was an increase in the amount of heroin seized in Hong Kong from 209 kilograms last year to 300 kilograms so far this year.
He explained that the rise was not due to an increase in the demand for drugs in the market.

"According to the Central Registry for Drug Abuse Records, the number of people abusing drugs had decreased from 14 281 people in the first nine months last year to 13 704 the same period this year," he said.
He attributed the increase in drug seizure to the good strategy and intelligence work of Police.
Mr Koo also took the opportunity to warn that anyone convicted of trafficking in heroin of over one kilogram will be liable to 20 years in jail on conviction.
19990819_009.e: Customs officers yesterday (Wednesday) smashed a packaging and distribution heroin centre following the seizure of 450 grams of no. 4 heroin, worth about $160,000, and the arrest of two brothers in Sha Tin.
After intensive investigations, officers from Customs Drug Investigation Bureau yesterday evening laid an ambush outside a residential building in Sha Tin Main Street.
About 10 pm, the officers intercepted two men while they were leaving the building.
Upon search, about 165 grams of suspected no. 4 heroin were seized.
The officers later gained entry into a premises in the same building where another 285 grams of suspected no. 4 heroin and some packaging apparatus were seized.
The seized drugs are believed for distribution in Kowloon areas.
The arrested men, aged 20 and 21, will be charged with "Trafficking in a Dangerous Drug" and will appear in Sha Tin Magistracy tomorrow.
Any person who is found guilty of the offence shall be liable to a maximum fine of $5 million and life imprisonment.
20000114_011.e: Seizure of Dangerous Drugs by Customs

Officers of the Customs Drug Investigation Bureau, in an anti-narcotics operation, arrested a 45-year-old man and seized 728 grams of suspected No. 4 heroin, worth about $700,000, in Wong Tai Sin today (Friday).
At about 8.20 am today, the officers intercepted the man outside Wong Tai Sin MTR Station and found the dangerous drugs in his possession.
"We believe the dangerous drugs are for distribution in Kowloon area," said a spokesman for the Customs and Excise Department.
The arrested man will appear in Kwun Tong Magistracy tomorrow to face a charge of "trafficking in a dangerous drug".
The maximum penalty for the offence is a fine of $5 million and life imprisonment.
20000320_005.e: Seizure of high-grade heroin by Customs
Officers of the Customs Drug Investigation Bureau, in an anti-narcotics operation, arrested a man and seized 350 grams of No. 4 high-grade heroin, worth about $150,000, in Fanling today (March 20).
At about 9.30 am today, the officers intercepted a goods vehicle at the road side of San Wan Road, Fanling.
Upon search, Customs officers found a slab of high grade No.4 heroin weighing 350 gram underneath the driver's seat.
The driver, a 21-year-old man, was arrested.
The arrested man will appear in Fanling Magistracy tomorrow to face a charge of "trafficking in a dangerous drug" under the Dangerous Drugs Ordinance.
The maximum penalty for the offence is a fine of $5 million and life imprisonment.
19980515_018.e: Seizure of No. 4 heroin by Customs
Customs officers today (Friday) seized 360 grams of high grade No. 4 heroin, worth about $300,000, from an incoming passenger at Lo Wu Control Point.
At about 9.30 am, a Hong Kong resident was intercepted by Customs officers for examination.
One slab of high grade No. 4 heroin weighing 360 grams was found strapped on his waist.
He was later brought to his residence in Sham Shui Po for a search but no further contraband was discovered.
The 49-year-old man will appear at Fanling Magistracy tomorrow to face charge of "Trafficking in a Dangerous Drug" under the Dangerous Drugs Ordinance.
Customs will continue to step up enforcement action to stem cross-border drug trafficking activity.
19991020_018.e: Customs officers yesterday (Tuesday) smashed a heroin manufacturing centre and arrested two men and two women in Tuen Mun and Fotan districts following the seizure of 2.41 kilograms of no. 4 heroin, worth about $1.5 million.
At about 2:30 pm yesterday, officers of Customs Drug Investigation Bureau intercepted a man outside a private carpark in Fotan.
As a result, 1,785 grams of suspected No.4 heroin were found in his possession.
Customs officers later searched a domestic unit nearby and found another 375 grams of No.4 heroin.
Another man and two women inside the premises were also arrested.
Further enquiries led to the seizure of another 250 grams of No. 4 heroin and a set of heroin manufacturing apparatus inside a domestic flat in Tuen Mun.
Seized from the arrestees were also cash $100,000 and gold ornament and jewellery valued at $400,000.
The arrested, aged from 20 to 32, will later be charged with "Trafficking in a Dangerous Drug" and "Manufacturing a Dangerous Drug" under the Dangerous Drugs Ordinance.
"We believe that this drug syndicate has been operating for about half a year and the drugs were mainly distributed to West Kowloon areas," a spokesman for the Customs and Excise Department said.
Last year, Customs officers neutralised 13 drug manufacturing and distribution centres with the seizure of 26 kilograms of No. 4 heroin and the arrest of 17 people.
The officers had so far this year smashed 15 similar centres with the seizure of 26.3 kilograms of No.4 heroin and the arrest of 45 suspects, the spokesman added.

19991126_008.e: Accessibility of Single Persons to Home Ownership Enhanced
The following is issued on behalf of the Housing Authority:
Single persons are allowed to apply for various subsidised home ownership schemes, starting from the next phase of the Home Ownership Scheme (HOS)/Home Purchase Loan Scheme (HPLS).
The Housing Authority's Home Ownership Committee (HOC) approved at today's (Friday) meeting to expand the coverage of subsidised home ownership schemes to single persons.
White Form (WF) singleton applicants can apply for the HOS/Private Sector Participation Scheme (PSPS) starting from HOS Phase 21B.
WF and Green Form (GF) singleton applicants as well as non-nuclear families can also apply for the HPLS from the next phase of the HPLS onwards.
A spokesman for the Authority said the new initiatives will enhance the opportunities and choices of single persons to acquire home ownership.
The monthly income and net asset limit for WF singleton applicants for HOS/PSPS and HPLS is set at $15,500 and $350,000 respectively.
Applicants have to be able to fulfil the residence requirement in addition to satisfying the income/asset limit and no-property-ownership requirement.

Considering that single persons are allowed to apply for subsidised home ownership schemes and the relaxation of the residence requirement for Public Rental Housing, the HOC also approved to relax the existing residence requirement for WF HOS/HPLS applicants.
With effect from HOS Phase 21B and the next HPLS application exercise onwards, only the applicant will be required to have fulfilled seven years' unconditional stay in Hong Kong.

The subsidy amount to be granted to single persons under the HPLS is half of the present rates, i.e. up to $200,000 / $250,000 for an interest-free housing loan or a monthly mortgage subsidy of $1,700 for WF applicants and $300,000 / $400,000 (interest-free loan) or $2,550 (monthly subsidy) for GF applicants.
Single GF and WF applicants will be allowed to buy flats up to 50 square meter saleable (2-bedroom flats) under the HOS/PSPS.
If they want to buy a small flat (around 20 square metre saleable), they can do so according to their normal flat selection priority.
But if they want to choose a larger HOS flat, their flat selection will be placed at the end of the queue.
They have to make a decision whether to wait for the larger flats when their turn for selection of small flats is due.
GF applicants will also be allowed to buy flats up to 50 square metre saleable under the HOS Secondary Market Scheme (SMS).
The HOC also decided to allow family members, other than the owner and his/her spouse, to be deleted from the home ownership record if they want to apply for subsidised housing separately.
"To deter possible abuse, the deletion of crucial members can only be effected at least two years after the family has joined a subsidised home ownership scheme," the spokesman said.

According to the findings of the General Household Survey conducted in the second quarter of 1999, the opening up of HOS/PSPS flats and HPLS to WF single persons will benefit about 32,500 one-person households living in private properties.
"The additional demand can be met as there is an increase in public housing production in the coming years," the spokesaman added.
The HOC also decided to give a single discount instead of three flexible discount rates for future Tenant Purchase Scheme (TPS) sale exercises.
This will come into effect when TPS Phase 3 is launched.
Flexible discounts were offered in TPS Phases 1 and 2.
Since almost all TPS buyers had opted for the highest discount rate, there is no need to offer flexible discounts, the spokesman explained.
20000419_014.e: Flat Size Restriction Relaxed for Singleton Home Purchasers
The following is issued on behalf of the Housing Authority:

To cater for the demand of single persons for larger flats, the Housing Authority has decided to allow singleton applicants to purchase subsidised home ownership flats irrespective of the flat size when all family households have made their flat selections.
As approved by the Housing Authority's Home Ownership Committee (HOC), the relaxation will be effective from the coming Home Ownership Scheme (HOS) Phase 22A.

All singleton applicants, whether Green Form (GF) or White Form (WF), will be invited to come forward for flat selection after all the family households, including non-nuclear WF households, have made their choice.
WF applicants are however still refrained from purchasing vacant flats under the Tenants Purchase Scheme.
Application from WF single persons were accepted for the first time under HOS Phase 21B.
There was an overwhelming response from singleton applicants.

According to the then prevailing policy, they could choose to buy a Small Flat up to 28 square metres saleable in their normal turn of flat selection, or purchase a larger HOS flat up to 51 square metres saleable when all family households have completed their flat selection.

If they wanted to buy flats sold under the Morgtage Subsidy Scheme, the Buy or Rent Option Scheme or vacant flats under the Tenants Purchase Scheme, single persons could only purchase flats up to 25 square metres saleable.
Among the singleton applicants of HOS Phase 21B, only 124 purchased Small Flats and 734 succeeded in choosing flats up to 51 square metres saleable.
In order to satisfy the aspiration of single-person families for larger accommodations, the Housing Authority has decided to relax the prevailing policy.

To achieve maximum efficiency, single-person families will be required to come for flat selection in one round and eligible applicants who had not been given a chance for flat selection in Phase 21B will be exempted from vetting interviews in the coming phase of sale, provided there are no changes that may affect their eligibility, said a spokesman for the Housing Authority.
19990730_025.e: Relaxation of HOS Resale Restriction Promotes Mobility
The following is issued on behalf of the Housing Authority:

After the relaxation of resale restriction period of Home Ownership Scheme (HOS) / Private Sector Participation Scheme (PSPS) flats, the number of applications for premium assessment for HOS flats before putting up for sale in the open market increases sharply.
The relaxation of the resale restriction came into effect on 1 June 1999.
Owners can sell their flats in the open market, subject to payment of a premium proportionate to the original discount, after five years from the first assignment.
This replaces the 10-year resale restriction rule.
Following the relaxation, the number of HOS/PSPS flats that can be put up for sale in the open market increases from 80,000 to 160,000 by June.
529 applications for premium assessment for HOS flats were received in June, which is twice the number recorded in May.

Out of the total applications received in June, 312 applications were submitted by the owners of the HOS courts in the 6th to 10th years while 217 applications were submitted by the owners of the post 10-year HOS courts.

The relaxation also allows owners to sell their flats under the HOS Secondary Market Scheme (SMS), after two years from the first assignment, to sitting public rental housing tenants and eligible buyers at a negotiated price without the payment of premium.
At the end of May, the number of HOS/PSPS flats between the 3rd and 5th years is about 40,000.

"Through the activities in the HOS Secondary Market, Green Form applicants can acquire home ownership and more rental flats can be recovered for allocation for the needy," a spokesman for the Housing Authority said.
Up to 8 July 1999, a total of 4,533 Letters of Nomination (LN) have been issued with 4,497 transactions recorded under the SMS.
At the same time, 3,392 public rental housing flats have been recovered for allocation to needy families.

Since the Green Form applicants are allowed to make use of the Home Purchase Loan to buy flats in the HOS Secondary Market starting July 1998, the number of transactions in the Secondary Market has been increased with an average of 360 transactions each month.
As at 8 July 1999, a total of 2,832 transactions recorded under the SMS have made use of the Home Purchase Loan.
19980723_004.e: Mortgage Subsidy Scheme to assist Home Ownership
The following is issued on behalf of the Housing Authority:

Public housing tenants affected by the Housing Authority's (HA) Comprehensive Redevelopment Programme (CRP) will be given a subsidy to purchase 'transfer' block flats or Home Ownership Scheme (HOS) flats, under a new scheme endorsed by the Authority's Home Ownership Committee (HOC) today (Thursday).
The Mortgage Subsidy Scheme (MSS) will be implemented from HOS Phase 20A onwards.
Tenants affected by CRP within three years are eligible to purchase HOS flats with this monthly subsidy which lasts for a period of six years.

"The scheme is one of the new initiatives announced in the 1998 Long Term Housing Strategy White Paper to help achieve the 70% home ownership target as the Chief Executive pledged in his Policy Address in 1997," a spokesman for the Authority said.
"Having regard to the price difference of various flat sizes and the affordability levels of affected tenants, two sets of subsidy rates will be introduced," the spokesman said.

For those purchasing one-bedroom, two- bedroom or three-bedroom flats, a total amount of $162,000 will be offered over six years. " They will be paid $3,000 every month for the first two years, $2,250 for the second two years, and $1,500 for the final two years," he said.
A subsidy of $81,000 will be given to the purchasers of small household flats -- $1,500, $1,125, and $750 monthly at 2-year intervals.

"To deter speculation, owners who resell their flats either to the HA or in the secondary market during the subsidy period are required to repay to the Authority the full amount of subsidy received," the spokesman said.
"This restriction will be lifted after the six years of subsidy," he added.
"Tenants paying market rents are not eligible for the mortgage subsidy but allowed to purchase the flats," he added.
A pilot scheme is selected in the Valley Road Estate CRP Phase 1 which is scheduled for clearance early next year.
Two blocks comprising 300 units in the new estate at Homantin South Phase 1 are earmarked as transfer blocks for sale.
Another block with 184 units is reserved to cater for additional demand of the tenants.
Affected tenants will be invited to apply next month.
The spokesman stressed that sufficient rental units would be allocated to the affected tenants who opt to continue to rent.
The HOC today also approved the average selling prices of flats to be sold in the pilot scheme.
Small household flats are sold at $578,400, i.e. $21,500/m2 Saleable Area (SA) or $1,150/ft2 Gross Floor Area (GFA).
The average prices of one-bedroom to three-bedroom Harmony-3 flats range from $918,900 to $1,360,700, i.e. $23,500/m2 SA or $1,600/ft2 GFA.
The flats are priced on the basis of 50% discount rate.
"Flexible discount options of 40% and 60% however will not be allowed as mortgage subsidies are given, "the spokesman said.
With the assistance of the MSS, most of the households will generally spend less than 40% of their total income in housing.
The total housing cost to rent is kept at a ratio below 1.84 on average.

Flats which are not purchased by the Valley Road CRP Phase 1 tenants will be offered for sale to public housing tenants living in estates in the same district and are affected by CRP within three years with the payment of mortgage subsidy.
"Any unsold flats remained after these two rounds of sale arrangements will be put up for sale in regular HOS sale programme," he added.
19990521_034.e: The following is issued on behalf of the Housing Authority:
To provide greater flexibility to Home Ownership Scheme flat owners, the ten-year resale restriction period will be shortened to five years with effect from 1st June, 1999.

According to the newly amended Housing Ordinance 1999, Home Ownership Scheme/Private Sector Participation Scheme (HOS/PSPS) flats are allowed to be sold in the HOS Secondary Market after two years from the date of the first assignment, and sold in the open market after five years.
All the HOS/PSPS flats sold from HOS Phase 3B onwards are affected by this legislative change.
At the end of May 1999, the number of HOS/PSPS flats exceeding five years from the first assignment is about 160,000 and the number of flats between two and five years is about 40,000.
Since the implementation of 10-year resale restriction in HOS Phase 3A, about 16,000 owners have paid the assessed premium and sold their flats in the open market.

The HOS Secondary Market was introduced in June 1997 and since then about 3,800 flats had been sold to public housing tenants or other eligible buyers, with more the 3,000 public housing units recovered.
This has contributed to the mobility of public housing units.

Starting from 1st June, 1999, HOS/PSPS flats within the first two years from the date of first assignment can be sold back to the Housing Authority or its nominated buyer at the original price, after deducting any unpaid mortgage and other prescribed deductible items.
During the third to fifth years from the date of first assignment, HOS/PSPS flat owners can either sell their flats to the Housing Authority or sell it in the HOS Secondary Market.
The Housing Authority will buy back the flats at the prevailing market value less the original discount percentage.
Should they choose to sell their flats in the Secondary Market, owners do not have to pay any premium, but have to apply for a "Certificate to Sell" first.

Within the five-year resale restriction period, if the Housing Authority does not exercise the option to buy back, owners can apply for premium assessment and then sell or rent the flat after paying the assessed premium.

For flats exceeding five years, owners can still sell them in the Secondary Market without paying any premium, or they can sell them in the open market after paying a premium to the Housing Authority.
It is Housing Authority's policy NOT to buy back HOS/PSPS flats which have expired the five year resale restriction period.
20000419_012.e: More Choices for HOS Secondary Market Buyers
The following is issued on behalf of Hong Kong Housing Authority:
With effect from April 15, 2000, flats sold under the first phase of the Tenants Purchase Scheme (TPS) can be resold under the Home Ownership Scheme's (HOS) Secondary Market Scheme (SMS).
Green Form buyers can now have more choices in flat type and court location in the SMS.
To tie in with the corresponding relaxation in HOS, one-person families will be allowed to buy flats of any size.
The number of Home Ownership Scheme/Private Sector Participation Scheme flats eligible for sale in the SMS reached 209 000 by the end of March 2000.
Together with the TPS units, the total number of flats eligible for the SMS will be much larger.
The annual turnover for this market in 1999/2000 was 3 524 units.
With wider choice in flat type and location, more transactions can be expected in the SMS.

The six estates under TPS Phase 1 which was launched in April 1998, include Wah Kwai Estate in Aberdeen, Fung Tak Estate in Wong Tai Sin, Heng On Estate in Ma On Shan, Wan Tau Tong Estate in Tai Po, Cheung On Estate in Tsing Yi and Kin Sang Estate in Tuen Mun.

The two-year resale restriction period for flats sold under the first batch of assignments expired on 15 April 2000 and more than one thousand flats will be eligible for sale in the SMS by the end of April this year.
The HOS Secondary Market was established in June 1997 to enable HOS units to be resold after entering the third year.
Owners can sell their flats to Green Form buyers without paying premium to the Housing Authority.

Green Form buyers include tenants of public housing estates and qualified residents of temporary housing areas, cottage areas, transit centres and holders of Green Form Certificates issued by the Housing Authority.
They will subsequently assume the responsibility of paying premium when they wish to sell the flat in the open market.
Successful Green Form applicants for the Home Purchase Loan Scheme can also use the loan to buy SMS flats.
For those who choose a flat priced below the loan amount, they will be given a monthly subsidy instead of the interest free loan.
19990303_059.e: Relaxation of Resale Restriction for flats

The Chief Executive in Council approved amended resale restrictions for flats sold under the Home Ownership Scheme (HOS) and Private Sector Participation Scheme (PSPS) to bring them in line with those approved for Tenants Purchase Scheme (TPS) flats.

The TPS, which was first launched in January 1998, aimed to provide at least 250,000 families living in public rental housing to buy their flats at reasonable and affordable prices over the next 10 years.

A spokesman for the Housing Bureau said today (Wednesday) that a TPS flat owner could sell the flat in the first two years from first assignment, to the Housing Authority (HA) at the original purchase price.

"After two years from first assignment," the spokesman said, " the flat can be sold to the HA at assessed market value less the original percentage discount and credit; or to a current or prospective public rental tenant, at a negotiated price without payment of a premium.
"The flat can be sold in the open market subject to payment of a premium proportionate to the original discount at the time of purchase, after five years from first assignment," he said.

"The Government considered that the resale restrictions for HOS flats and PSPS flats should be relaxed in line with those under the TPS because these are all subsidised flat sale schemes administered by the HA," the spokesman said.

"The turnover of HOS and PSPS flats can be increased by relaxing the resale restrictions, helping to meet the demand for subsidised home ownership flats and freeing public rental flats for reallocation to people in genuine need, " he said.
Moreover, the buy back price for HOS, PSPS and TPS flats is to be revised so as to relate to the discount enjoyed by the owner at the time of original purchase, the spokesman added.
The proposal will allow an addition of 16,000 HOS and PSPS flats to be sold in the secondary market and 80,000 flats in the open market.
Amendments to the Schedule to the Housing Ordinance will be made to put these approved resale restrictions into effect.
The proposal will be submitted to the Legislative Council in mid March 1999.
19990930_030.e: New Measures To Enhance Singletons' Accessibility to Public Housing
A three-pronged approach is being considered by the Housing Authority to enhance the accessibility of non-elderly single persons to public rental housing (PRH) and subsidised home ownership.

As a first step, the Authority's Rental Housing Committee (RHC) approved at today's (Thursday) meeting to allow singleton clearees who satisfy the rehousing eligibility criteria the same access to public rental housing irrespective of their age.

Later on, the Home Ownership Committee (HOC) will decide whether to expand the coverage of home ownership schemes to single persons, and whether to allow unmarried family members to delete from the home ownership records if they want to apply for subsidised housing separately.
A spokesman for the Authority said while enhancing single persons' accessibility to public housing, the new initiatives can also help shorten their waiting time.
They are introduced in response to the pledges made in the Long Term Housing Strategy White Paper and the 1998 Housing Policy Booklet.
He said in allocating public housing resources, priority has always been given to households with greater needs.
Single persons, except the elderly, are currently not accorded with preferential treatment as a result of the shortage of small flats.

At present, the average waiting time for PRH for non-elderly single persons is nine years, and singleton squatters aged below 50 who are affected by Government clearance operations are not allowed to opt for self-contained PRH flats.
Single persons also have limited access to subsidised home ownership schemes.

"As time evolves, it is necessary to review the eligibility criteria for non-elderly single persons in view of an increased supply of housing production in the coming years and the yearning for home ownership amongst the community," the spokesman explained.

To meet the new demand in PRH, the Authority will increase the supply of 6,000 additional small flats by converting 1,600 3-Bedroom flats scheduled for completion up to 2003/04 into self-contained small flats and reviewing the production and flat mix for housing projects to be completed after 2003/04.
In addition, the Authority will continue to arrange trawling exercises to create suitable small vacant flats to supplement the supply.

As to home ownership, the Authority's HOC is studying proposals to accept White Form (WF) applications from single persons for Home Ownership Scheme/Private Sector Participation Scheme (HOS/PSPS), and singleton applications as well as WF applications from non-nuclear families for Home Purchase Loan Scheme (HPLS).
The HOC will meet in November to decide on the matters.
They will also discuss the following items in relation to the proposals:
--to set the monthly income and net asset limits for WF singleton applicants for HOS/PSPS/HPLS at $15,500 and $350,000 respectively.
--to allow both WF and Green Form (GF) singletons under HOS/PSPS and Green Form (GF) applicants under the Secondary Market Scheme to buy flats up to 50 sq.m. (2-Bedroom flats).

--to set the loan/subsidy amount of HPLS for single persons at half of the present rates, i.e. $200,000/$250,000 loan or $1,700 monthly subsidy for WF and $300,000/$400,000 loan or $2,550 monthly subsidy for GF.
Subject to approval by relevant Committees, these initiatives will take immediate effect except for WF applicants to join HOS/PSPS in HOS Phase 21B to be launched at the end of this year.
For HPLS, single persons can apply in the next exercise.
The spokesman stressed that the new initiatives will have minimal impact on the housing pledges for households of other sizes as there is an increased housing production in the coming years.
At today's meeting, the Rental Housing Committee also noted the progress on the enforcement action against unauthorised installation of air-conditioners in rental estates.
In Stage Two of the three-year exercise, a total of 9,269 cases were handled between November 1998 to July 1999, in which almost 99% have been rectified.
Stage Three, the final stage of the exercise, will commence in October to cover about 12,500 unauthorised window-type air-conditioners scattered in 61 estates.
A case by case approach will be adopted to assist tenants in rectifying their installations.
Notice-to-Quit will be served on those tenants who ignore warnings and show no intention to rectify.
19990204_025.e: HOS Resale Restriction Relaxed

Resale restriction period for Home Ownership Scheme (HOS)/Private Sector Participation Scheme flats will be shortened to enhance the attractiveness of HOS and help promote mobility of flats, both in the open market and the secondary HOS market.
It is intended that through activities in the secondary HOS market, more rental flats can be recovered for allocation to needy families.
The approval to relax the existing resale restrictions was given today (Thursday) by the Housing Authority's Home Ownership Committee (HOC).
The relaxation is also intended to tie in with the arrangements under the Tenants Purchase Scheme by bringing in a uniformed and consistent approach in resale restrictions for the two schemes.
Owners can sell their flats in the open market, subject to payment of a premium proportionate to the original discount, after five years from first assignment.
This will replace the existing 10-year resale restriction rule.
A spokesman for the Authority said: "The Authority will not buy back flats after the five-year restriction period since these flats can be sold in the open market."

Besides, HOS flats could be put on sale in the HOS secondary market a year earlier following the relaxation that allows owners to sell their flats, between two to five years of first assignment, to sitting public rental housing tenants and Waiting List applicants at a negotiated price without the payment of premium.
Another option for these HOS owners is to apply to sell their flats back to the Authority at assessed market value less the original discount.
"This is a revised basis for determining buy-back price of HOS flats which relates the price assessment to the original discount the purchasers enjoyed at the initial purchase,"

"The new provision, which replaces the original HA practice of buying back at prevailing HOS price, will be a more equitable arrangement particularly in light of the various discounts rates used in different phases of sale," the spokesman added.
Also with the relaxation, the Authority would accept offers of buy-back at original price from owners whose property is within two years of first assignment.
Following the approval, actions will be taken to amend the Schedule to the Housing Ordinance to provide legal teeth to the new resale criteria.

Meanwhile, the HOC also reviewed the management fees for 102 HOS estates, approving to freeze the rates for 80 of them and increase those of another 21 after considering the financial position of the courts' management funds.

The spokesman said, "With the joint efforts of the departmental staff and the property management agents, we have succeeded in maintaining handsome surplus for 80 estates where the current fee levels can be frozen for another fiscal year."
At present, all HOS estates are managed by private management agents under the supervision of the Housing Department.
Management fees are used to cover management and maintenance expenses and are charged on a cost-recovery basis.
The average management fee per square meter is $9.14 for all HOS estates.
The monthly management fees for 21 HOS estates, however, will be revised to range from $399 to $710 a month, a slight increase in $2 to $32 per flat.
The increase, to be effective for a year from 1 April, is considered necessary to maintain a healthy financial position of the management funds.

The Committee also noted that the Supervision Cost, charged by the Housing Department to cover the cost of supervisory staff and administrative overheads in the management fee, will be frozen at $30.30 per flat per month in the next financial year for the third consecutive year.
19990114_009.e: New measures to enhance recovery of PRH flats
The following is issued on behalf of the Housing Authority:
The Housing Authority will take new measures to ensure the early recovery of public rental housing (PRH) flats under various home ownership schemes.
At present, these schemes include the Home Ownership Scheme (HOS), the Private Sector Participation Scheme (PSPS) and the Home Purchase Loan Scheme (HPLS).
The measures, applicable to all home ownership schemes to be announced after 14 January 1999, were endorsed by the Authority's Rental Housing Committee (RHC) at a meeting today (Thursday).
They will help deter tenants who tend to hold on to their PRH units after purchasing a flat under HOS, PSPS and HPLS through Green Forms.

Under the new measures, tenants who make use of Green Forms to purchase a flat under these schemes will be asked to tender notices-to-quit (NTQ) at the time of taking over their HOS/PSPS flats or effecting the assignment in the case of HPLS to terminate their tenancies and surrender the PRH flats within one calendar month.
For any extended stay after the expiry of the NTQ, the tenants concerned will be charged an occupation fee equivalent to three times the net rent plus rates.
In the case of market rent payers, the amount will be equivalent to the market rent or three times the net rent plus rates, whichever is higher.
The time ceiling allowed for PRH tenants to surrender their flats will be three months.
Any application for further extension will normally not be considered.
Exceptional cases on strong compassionate ground will have to be considered by the Regional Chief Manager/Management on individual merits.
Currently, successful Green Form applicants of various home ownership schemes are required to surrender their PRH unit within two calendar months subsequent to taking over of their new flat.
However, tenants used to put forth different reasons such as decoration/fitting-out difficulties and social/medical problems in order to extend their holding over period.
There was also no maximum of the time limit for these tenants to surrender their PRH flats.
A spokesman for the Authority said in principle, the Authority can cease subsidies to those occupiers who fail to deliver up vacant possession of the PRH flats after the expiry of the NTQ.

"It is inequitable to allow PRH tenants in possession of self-owned flats to enjoy double housing benefits for any prolonged period," said the spokesman, adding that the new time frame has already taken into account the difficulties that may arise for tenants to vacate their PRH flats within too short a period of time.
Those successful Green Form applicants of home ownership schemes announced prior to 14 January 1999 will be reminded of the need to surrender the PRH units within two calendar months.
An occupation fee equivalent to three times the net rent plus rates will be charged for any extended stay.
In the case of market rent payers, the amount will be equivalent to the market rent or three times the net rent plus rates, whichever is higher.

The spokesman said the new measures are in line with the recommendations of the Office of Ombudsman, which in an investigation unveiled that about 20 per cent (8,955) of the PRH flats surrendered by successful applicants of various home ownership schemes for the period 1992/93 to 1996/97 were recovered beyond the normal two-month time frame.

Other measures corresponding to the Ombudsman's recommendations include the enhancement of Housing Department's IT system to facilitate Estate Housing Managers and the respective District Senior Housing Managers to monitor the flat recovery situation.

19981103_009.e: Outlying islands ferry service licences awarded

The Commissioner for Transport, Mrs Fanny Law, today (Tuesday) announced that the licences to operate various outlying islands ferry routes would be awarded to Hongkong and Yaumati Ferry Company Limited (HYF) and Hong Kong & Kowloon Ferry Limited (HKK).
These ferry licences are for a period of three years, starting April 1, 1999 to March 31, 2002.
A total of eight routes, grouped into three packages, were offered for open tender in September.
HYF will provide ferry services under Package I and II, while HKK will operate routes under Package III.
Package I comprises ferry services between Cheung Chau - Central, Cheung Chau - Kowloon Point (excursion route) and an inter-islands route.
Package II is made up of services between Mui Wo - Central; Mui Wo - Kowloon Point (excursion route) and Peng Chau - Central.
Package III covers Yung Shue Wan - Central route and Sok Kwu Wan - Central route which serve mainly residents of the Lamma Island.
Speaking at a press conference on the tender results, Mrs Law said: "The tender exercise has attracted a good turnout.
"It enhances competition and serves to widen the trawl for the Government to locate the most suitable operators for outlying islands ferry services."
The Transport Department had received altogether 10 bids from six companies when the tender closed on October 12.
An inter-departmental assessment committee chaired by a Deputy Commissioner for Transport had been set up to study the tenders.
Other members included representatives from the Transport Department, Marine Department, Home Affairs Department, Department of Justice and the Independent Commission Against Corruption.
The Tender Assessment Committee evaluated tenders on the basis of:
* the level and quality of services proposed;
* fares and passenger facilities proposed;
* suitability and quality of vessels proposed;
* the corporate and financial capabilities of the tenderers;
* the quality and fares of freight services proposed; and
* proposed marine contingency plans.
Mrs Law noted that the two successful tenderers are experienced operators in providing ferry services in Hong Kong.
At present, HYF is running 12 franchised ferry routes and six licensed services, while HKK takes on three licensed ferry services.
"Both HYF and HKK have committed in their bids the provision of quality ferry services at reasonable fares for passengers.
"New vessels will be purchased.
The number of trips will be increased while journey time will be reduced with the employment of more high speed vessels.

"Ferry services for the outlying islands, which are essential due to a lack of land transportation alternatives, will be much improved, while fares will remain at levels similar to those of existing ones," Mrs Law said.
For instance, fare for each single trip to Cheung Chau, Mui Wo and Peng Chau from Central by fast ferries will be reduced from $24 to $20 in 1999 and $21 in 2000.
On the employment of HYF staff, Mrs Law pointed out that HYF would retain most of its existing staff for operating these new licensed ferry services.
"HKK will recruit a number of HYF staff to fill all posts required to operate their new licensed services.
"The number of staff to be recruited by HKK should not be less than those currently deployed by HYF for the same ferry services," she added.
Mrs Law assured the public that the Government would provide all necessary assistance for both companies in gearing up their operation to commence services in April next year.
"We trust that HYF and HKK will cooperate with each other in ensuring a smooth transition.
"Early meetings between the two operators will be arranged to discuss and firm up essential detailed arrangements," she said.
19990316_007.e: Changes in Ferry Services on 1 April 1999

The Transport Department announces today the operational details of the outlying island, new town and inner harbour licensed ferry services on April 1, 1999 and reminds passengers of the new timetables and fares of these services.

"After the expiry of the current franchise on March 31, HYF's outlying island, new town and inner harbour ferry services as well as "Star" Ferry's Central - Hung Hom service will be operated as licensed services by five ferry operators : HYF, "Star" Ferry, Hong Kong and Kowloon Ferry Company Limited (HKK), Discovery Bay Transportation Services Limited (DBTSL) and Shun Tak Ferries Limited," a spokesman said.
"There will be considerable changes in the timetable, operating hours as well as fares on these services."
All the outlying island services, except the Yung Shue Wan and Sok Kwu Wan services, will continue to be operated by HYF after March 31.
The Yung Shue Wan and Sok Kwu Wan services will be operated by HKK.
These services to the Lamma Island will operate from Central Pier No. 5.

The first ferry trip operated by HYF on April 1, will depart at 12.30 am from Central Pier No. 6 to Cheung Chau, while the first ferry trip operated by HKK will depart at 12.30 am from Central Pier No. 5 to Yung Shue Wan.
"Overall speaking, more ferry trips will be provided to Cheung Chau (from 58 to 80 trips), Mui Wo (From 49 to 60 trips) and Peng Chau (from 46 to 53 trips).
With the changes in timetable and with a mixture of fast and slow ferries service, passengers are advised to check carefully the sailings they want to take.
In addition, overnight trips will be provided to these outlying islands.
The number of trips for the Yung Shue Wan (from 46 to 60 trips) and Sok Kwu Wan services (from 20 to 22 trips) will also be increased."
For the new town and inner harbour services, the operating hours will be similar to the existing services, but some of them will operate from different piers after March 31, e.g.

Shun Tak's Tuen Mun service will operate from Central Pier No. 4, "Star" Ferry's two Hung Hom services will operate from Hung Hom (South) Pier and HYF's Hung Hom - North Point service will operate from Hung Hom (North) Pier.

Passengers can later find the detailed timetable, operating hours and fares of all these licensed services at TD's Homepage (http://www.info.gov.hk/td/) as well as the homepage of HYF (http://www.hkf.com).
Distribution of timetables on ferry piers will begin on March 23, 1999.
"As explained above, some of the ferry services will operate at different piers after March 31.
Though clear directional signs will be provided, passengers are advised to check carefully to ensure boarding the night service.

Given the considerable changes to the operational details, passengers are also advised to check carefully the timetable, operating hours and fares of the ferry services before they plan their trips," the spokesman said.

"Although the transition of ferry services is expected to be smooth, passengers should arrive at the piers earlier in the initial period of the new operation and allow themselves more time to react to any unforeseen delay," he said.
The Transport Department will operate a coordinating centre to ensure a smooth transition of ferry services.
The centre will be activated on March 31, 1999 and oversee the initial operation of the new services.

19980723_002.e: Invitation to indicate interest in ferry operation

The Transport Department invites operators to indicate whether they are interested in taking up 12 ferry routes currently operated by Hongkong and Yaumati Ferry Company Limited (HYF) from April 1, 1999.
The franchise for HYF to operate these routes will expire on March 31 next year.
Speaking on the invitation, a spokesman for the department said: "The Government is now actively negotiating with HYF on the terms of its new franchise.
"However, if progress is unsatisfactory, the Government may consider tendering out ferry services in a number of packages.
"The invitation to indicate interest is to gauge market's response in operating these routes."
The 12 routes, comprising mainly services for the outlying islands, Tuen Mun and the inner harbour, are grouped into seven packages.
The packages are:
* Package A: Central - Cheung Chau
Inner-islands (Peng Chau - Mui Wo - Chi Ma
Wan - Cheung Chau)
* Package B: Central - Mui Wo
Central - Peng Chau
* Package C: Central - Yung Shue Wan
Central - Sok Kwu Wan
* Package D: Central - Tuen Mun
* Package E: Tsim Sha Tsui East - Central
* Package F: North Point - Kwun Tong
North Point - Hung Hom
North Point - Kowloon City
* Package G: Wan Chai - Hung Hom
The spokesman noted that the invitation is not a tender exercise.
It is issued on a non-committal basis and will not prejudice current negotiations with HYF.

"The Government aims to conclude the negotiation with HYF as soon as possible so as to ensure ferry services, particular those essential routes serving the outlying islands, will be maintained," he added.
Interested parties may indicate interest in operating one or a combination of several packages.
They are required to submit information on the companies' experience and competence in operating ferry services as well as the vessels available for deployment by April 1, 1999.
"HYF is also welcome to indicate its interest," the spokesman said.
Forms and details of the ferry services can be obtained from the Transport Department, Room 4021, 40th floor, Immigration Tower, 7 Gloucester Road, Wan Chai, Hong Kong.
