Litigants are therefore able to challenge legislation on the basis that it is inconsistent with the provisions in the Basic Law.
Those provisions include Article 39, which provides for the continued implementation of the ICCPR as applied to Hong Kong.
I have already mentioned the case in which the legality of the Provisional Legislative Council was unsuccessfully challenged.
That case also involved an assertion that the common law had not survived Reunification, since it had not been positively adopted as part of the laws of the SAR.
Article 160 of the Basic Law provides that, upon the establishment of the Hong Kong SAR, the laws previously in force in Hong Kong 'shall be adopted as laws of the Region'.
The court unanimously held that this article did not require any formal adoption of the laws previously in force and so the common law did survive Reunification.
There have also been challenges to the immigration legislation which introduced the certificate of entitlement scheme, and which implemented other relevant provisions of the Basic Law.

Those cases have now been heard by the Court of First Instance and the Court of Appeal and may yet be appealed to the Court of Final Appeal and so my following comments are subject to the outcome of any such appeal.
The scheme itself was attacked on four main grounds.

First, it was argued that a person who claims the right of abode in Hong Kong by descent is entitled under the Basic Law to entry into Hong Kong before he or she establishes the facts giving rise to the claim.
It was therefore claimed that those persons could not be required to produce a certificate of entitlement before being allowed entry.

Secondly, it was argued that it was not permissible to use immigration legislation as a means of avoiding the social problems that would arise if large numbers of Mainland children exercised their right of abode at the same time.
Thirdly, it was argued that the scheme was incompatible with Article 8(4) of the Hong Kong Bill of Rights Ordinance, since it arbitrarily deprived persons of the right of abode in Hong Kong.
Fourthly, it was argued that the scheme could not lawfully be made retrospective to 1 July 1997.
The first three arguments were rejected by the court.

The Basic Law merely identifies the categories of persons who have the right of abode in Hong Kong, and leaves the question as to how the facts on which the claim to right of abode should be established to be determined by the legislature.

Moreover, the Basic Law itself requires persons living in Mainland China who seek to exercise their right of abode in Hong Kong to obtain a one-way exit permit from the Chinese authorities before coming to Hong Kong.

The fact that those claiming the right of abode by descent were singled out for the certificate of entitlement scheme did not deprive them of their right to enter Hong Kong, nor was it an arbitrary scheme.
With regard to provision making the legislative scheme retrospective to July 1, 1997, the court upheld the provision.
It held that the restrictions on the exercise of the right of abode were already contained in the Basic Law, which was in place on July 1, 1997.
It nevertheless held that the scheme did not apply to persons in Hong Kong who arrived before that date even though their presence in Hong Kong before that date was unlawful.
Two particular aspects of the legislation have also been challenged.

A provision requiring children born out of wedlock to derive their right of abode through their mothers and not through their fathers was declared to contravene the Basic Law and was excised from the legislation.
Such children were considered to be within the categories of children who are given the right of abode.

Another provision restricting the right of abode of children born outside Hong Kong to those whose mother or father had acquired the right of abode in Hong Kong by the date of their birth was at first held to contravene the Basic Law.
However, on appeal it was held that this provision reflected the plain meaning of the words of the Basic Law.
There is one further area, namely regulation of the civil service, which has been the subject of a challenge under the Basic Law.

Before Reunification, the regulation of the civil service was achieved by means of Colonial Regulations, issued by the Secretary of State to the Governor, and regulations made under them by the Governor.
After Reunification, the Chief Executive issued an Executive Order in respect of the Civil Service, under Article 48(4) of the Basic Law, and issued regulations under that Order.
These instruments were challenged by the Association of Expatriate Civil Servants.

The Basic Law requires that the previous system in respect of public servants 'shall be maintained', and that the appointment and removal of public officers shall be 'in accordance with legal procedures'.
It was argued that these requirements had not been satisfied, as the new scheme had not been approved by the Legislative Council.
The court rejected the challenge, holding that the previous system was established by executive action and could therefore be maintained in a similar manner.
The court did, however, declare that public officers were not bound by one provision which prohibited a public officer under interdiction from leaving Hong Kong without permission.
It was held that this was a restriction on the freedom to leave Hong Kong, protected by Article 8(2) of the Bill of Rights, and the restriction was not 'provided by law'.
The court therefore declared that holders of public office to whom the Executive Order applies were not bound by that restriction.
Human Rights and the Rule of Law
What do these court challenges and decisions demonstrate?
In my view, they demonstrate that human rights are fully protected in the SAR by an independent Judiciary, and that the rule of law is as strong as ever.
Members of the community are able to challenge laws and procedures that they consider to be inconsistent with the ICCPR, or the Basic Law, and in some cases those challenges have been successful.
They also demonstrate that the Provisional Legislative Council was lawfully established and that the immigration legislation enacted by it was, with the exception of one provision, lawfully enacted.
Challenges ahead
What of the future?
There are many significant legal challenges ahead.

As many of you may know, Article 23 of the Basic Law provides that the Hong Kong SAR shall enact laws on its own to prohibit any act of treason, secession, sedition, or subversion against the Central People's Government.

This provision is a reflection of Hong Kong's high degree of autonomy since, even though the offences referred to are offences against the Central People's Government, the SAR is to enact its own legislation in respect of them.
In preparing this legislation, the SAR Government will have full regard to the provisions in the ICCPR and the Basic Law concerning freedom of speech and freedom of assembly.
It will also take into account public opinion.
The proposals will be fully debated by the members of the Legislative Council and will need to be acceptable to them.
Another challenge lying ahead is the development of a bilingual legal system in Hong Kong.
The foundations for this have already been laid, in that all our Ordinances are bilingual, and all courts are allowed to operate in either the English or Chinese language.
A large proportion of cases heard in the magistracies are already conducted in Cantonese.
In developing bilingualism, we are determined that the quality of the administration of justice should be maintained.
We will continue to develop a body of jurisprudence in respect of the Basic Law.

20000225_007.e: Two unlicensed food factory operators arrested in Mong Kok
The Food and Environmental Hygiene Department (FEHD) continued its blitz operations in Mong Kok this (Friday) afternoon against unlicensed food factories selling snacks and cooked food.

Today's operation, led by Senior Health Inspector Mr Lee Tse-wah, resulted in the arrest of two operators who were later charged with running an unlicensed food factory and breaching prohibition order respectively.
In addition, two operators of licensed food factories were summonsed for exposing food to risk of contamination.
About 50 kilogrammes of open food were seized under Section 59 of the Public Health and Municipal Services Ordinance, Cap 132.

Mr Lee said: "To safeguard public health and maintain environmental hygiene, we have stepped up enforcement action since January this year by carrying out daily summary arrest operations against illegal food factories selling snacks and cooked food in the district."
Since January 10, 45 summary arrests have been made against operators of unlicensed food factories in Mong Kok while a total of 573 kilogrammes of exposed food were seized.
Among the 45 prosecutions so far, 38 of them had already been heard and convicted in court.
The average fine of operating unlicensed food factories imposed is $3,000 while that of exposing food to risk of contamination is $1,000.
"The Department will continue to launch stringent summary arrest operations against unlicensed food factories in the district until the situation has improved," Mr Lee added.
19990305_027.e: USD blitz operations against unlicensed food businesses
The following is issued on behalf of the Provisional Urban Council:
The Urban Services Department will step up law enforcement actions against operators of unlicensed food premises selling cooked food and snacks in the urban area.

A spokesman for the Department said today (Friday), "Recently, there has been concern over a proliferation of small food factories selling snacks and cooked food in sub-divided shop units which are mostly unlicensable.
Their hygiene standards are poor, tenancies are short and proprietors often change."
"Also, there have even been cases that 'cooked food hawkers' operate on private vacant building sites," he said.
The spokesman said that because of the transient nature of these businesses, the existing enforcement actions by way of summons and application for court orders might not be effective.

Therefore, in addition to normal proceedings and applications for Prohibition Order or Closure Order, USD will mount blitz summary arrest operations, starting next week, against operators of these types of food business, aiming at arresting any person on the spot, charging and bringing them to court as soon as possible.
"These operations will be carried out every day and such unlicensed food shops may be raided consecutively for a number of days," he said.
The maximum penalty for operating unlicensed food business is a fine of $50,000, an imprisonment of six months and a daily fine of $900.
19991104_004.e: Blitz operations stepped up against cooked food exposure
The Urban Services Department has stepped up enforcement action in Mong Kok district against exposure of cooked food by food factories selling snacks.

A USD spokesman said today (Thursday) that a series of blitz operations were conducted in the district to prevent further proliferation of unlicensed food factories selling snacks and to ensure the proper storage of cooked food items to safeguard public health.
Last month, nine prosecutions were taken out against food factories selling snacks for display of food without cover.
Another nine prosecutions were also taken out against operators for running unlicensed food factories selling snacks.
All the exposed cooked food found at these premises were seized under section 59 of the Public Health and Municipal Services Ordinance, Cap 132.

Under the Food Business (Urban Council) By-laws, those who are convicted of improper storage of cooked food are liable to a maximum fine of $10,000, an imprisonment of three months as well as a daily fine of $300.
Those who operate unlicensed food premises are subject to a maximum fine of $50,000, an imprisonment of six months as well as a daily fine of $900.
"USD will continue to mount blitz operations to safeguard public health and safety," he said.
20000211_003.e: FEHD blitz operations to ensure food hygiene
The Food and Environmental Hygiene Department (FEHD) mounted a blitz operation in Mong Kok today (Friday) against improper handling of food items by delivery workers.

The Mong Kok District Environmental Hygiene Superintendent, Mr Yeung Shun-kui said: "Our health inspectors conducted surprise inspections to some 20 food shops selling snacks and cooked food in the district early this morning to check whether delivery workers of food suppliers had properly handled the food items.
"We found that four of these shops, three in Dundas Street and one in Bute Street, had food items placed on the pavement in front of the shops, unattended, posing great health risk to customers.
"The food items included bean curd, 'pig blood' pudding, fish balls, fish meat and soya bean juice," he said.
All the food items, weighing 145 kilogrammes, were seized under Section 59 of the Public Health and Municipal Services Ordinance.
One of the delivery workers was located and summonsed for failing to protect food from risk of contamination.
Warnings were also given to some shop operators against improper handling of food items.

Mr Yeung noted: "Under Section 10 of the Food Business Regulation, it is an offence for those engaged in food business to place any open food as to involve any risk of contamination or to wrap up or bring any open food into direct contact with any printed newspaper, unclean paper or wrapping material.
"Upon conviction, the maximum penalty is a fine of $10,000 and an imprisonment of three months plus a daily fine of $300."
Meanwhile, blitz operations are continuing in Mong Kok against unlicensed food shops selling snacks and cooked food.

Mr Yeung said: "Since January 10, 36 summary arrests were made against the unlicensed operators who were later charged with the offences of operating unlicensed food factories and exposing food to risk of contamination."
During a series of operations, a total of 468 kilogrammes of exposed cooked food were seized.
Among the 36 prosecutions so far, 25 of them had already been heard and sentenced in court.
The average fine of operating unlicensed food factories imposed is $3,000 while that of exposing food to risk of contamination is $1,000.
He stressed that FEHD would continue to take stringent enforcement actions against unhygienic food handlers and unlicensed food shops to safeguard public health and environmental hygiene.
19991130_004.e: Stepped up actions against unlicensed food factories

The Urban Services Department has mounted blitz operations against unlicensed food factories selling cooked food and snacks in a vacant site in Causeway Bay to safeguard public health and food safety.

A spokesman for the Department said today (Tuesday) that it has come to the department's attention that the vacant site situated at Russell Street opposite Times Square had been turned into a flea market and opened for business since last Sunday.
Among the stalls, 22 were found operating in the some 560-square-meter site, selling cooked food and snacks such as fish balls, cuttlefish, dim sum and pork intestine.
In the last two days, special summary arrest operations were mounted, resulting in the arrest of 12 operators who were later charged with running food factories without a licence.
Under the Food Business (Urban Council) By-laws, the maximum penalty for operating unlicensed food premises is a fine of $50,000, an imprisonment of six months and a daily fine of $900.
"We will not tolerate the existence of such unlicensed food factories and will continue our enforcement actions until all these illegal premises have stopped business, " the spokesman said.

Meanwhile, as a result of the blitz summary arrest operations, launched in urban blackspots between November 25 and 27, USD has arrested 12 operators for running unlicensed food premises and three for breaching prohibition order.
Some 150 kilograms of cooked food exposed to risk of contamination were seized for disposal.
19980821_003.e: The following is issued on behalf of the Provisional Urban Council:
The Urban Services Department (USD) has stepped up measures to help prevent the spread of cholera.

A Department spokesman said today (Friday) that these measures included increasing the frequency of inspections to restaurants and food premises and stepping up prosecution actions against irregularities found on these premises.
Such irregularities included storing food in open space and preparing food on the pavement in front of their shops.

For the sake of public health, the Department has also taken stringent enforcement actions against unlicensable food premises by summary arrest operations and increased raids against illegal hawkers selling cooked food and restricted food, in particular, shellfish, non-bottled drinks and Siu Mei and Lo Mei.
USD today completed the first round of inspection to 1,405 licensed food premises of grade C under the Departments selective inspection system.

Forty-eight of them were prosecuted for, among other things, exposing food in open space, preparing food on the pavement at shop fronts, failing to keep the food room clean and causing obstructions in public places.

During the period between August 14 and 21, USD had arrested 43 unlicensed hawkers selling cooked food and restricted food and taken out 47 summonses against unlicensable food premises for operating without a licence.
The Department had also carried out 12 summary arrest operations in the urban area and arrested eight operators of unlicensable food premises for unlicensed operation.
The spokesman said that to further improve hygiene in food premises, the Department would conduct another round of blitz operations from August 24 to September 19.

The operations will cover all licensed food premises of grade B and C, cooked food stalls in markets, hawker bazaars and public housing estates, and all unlicensed food premises including those applying for licence.

Apart from giving advice on food, personal and environmental hygiene in preventing cholera, USD health inspectors will during the inspection focus on inadequate cooking of seafood, cross-contamination of raw and cooked food and inadequate reheating of food.
"USD will not tolerate such unhygienic practices by food premises and will prosecute the operators to safeguard public health," the spokesman said.
19991125_007.e: USD blitz operations against unlicensed food shops

The Urban Services Department has stepped up law enforcement action against operators of unlicensed food factories selling cooked food and snacks in urban blackspots, aiming at bringing them to court as soon as possible.
A spokesman for the Department said today (Thursday) that blitz summary arrest operations against these operators were launched today in the urban area, resulting in the arrest of three operators.
They were charged with the offences of operating unlicensed food factories and exposing food to risk of contamination.
A total of 80 kilograms of cooked food exposed to risk of contamination were also seized for disposal under Section 59 of the Public Health and Municipal Services Ordinance, Cap 132.
Recently, there has been a proliferation of small scale food factories selling snacks and cooked food in sub-divided shop units.
Most of these premises are not qualified for a food licence and their hygiene standards are poor.
"Very often, their tenancies are short and proprietors change frequently, making prosecution action difficult to stop this illegal food business," the spokesman said.
To speed up the prosecution procedures and the application for prohibition and closure orders, arrest actions were taken in addition to normal prosecution by summonses.
As a result, the defendants can be taken to court in a couple of days.
The maximum penalty for operating unlicensed food premises is a fine of $50,000, an imprisonment of six months and a daily fine of $900.
"Besides, USD health inspectors will also take stringent enforcement action against improper storage of open food in these food premises," the spokesman said.

Under the Food Business (Urban Council) By-laws, those who are convicted of improper storage of cooked food are subject to a maximum fine of $10,000, an imprisonment of three months plus a daily fine of $300.
"USD will continue to step up blitz operations against unlicensed and unhygienic food premises to ensure public health and safety," the spokesman stressed.
20000110_005.e: FEHD blitz operations against unlicensed food shops
The Food and Environmental Hygiene Department (FEHD) launched a blitz operation in Mong Kok today (Monday) against operators of unlicensed food factories selling snacks and cooked food.

The Mong Kok Environmental Hygiene Superintendent, Mr Yeung Shun-kui said: "To safeguard public health and environmental hygiene, blitz summary arrest operations against these operators were launched today in the district, resulting in the arrest of six operators.
They have been charged with the offences of operating unlicensed food factories, breaching prohibition order and exposing food to risk of contamination."
A total of 93 kilogrammes of cooked food exposed to risk of contamination were also seized for disposal under Section 59 of the Public Health and Municipal Services Ordinance, Cap 132.
Mr Yeung noted: "Recently, there has been a proliferation of small scale food factories selling snacks and cooked food in sub-divided shop units in Mong Kok district without a licence.
"Most of these premises are not qualified for a food licence because of poor hygiene standards.
The food items sold by these premises are not properly covered, posing health hazards to customers.
Besides, unlicensed food businesses also caused environmental nuisance to nearby residents," he added.
He said: "To speed up the prosecution procedures, summary arrest actions were taken against these operators in addition to normal prosecution by summonses.
As a result, the defendants can be taken to court in a couple of days."
In 1999, a total of 112 summary arrests were made and 243 summonses issued in Mong Kok district in relation to unlicensed food shops.
The maximum penalty for operating unlicensed food premises is a fine of $50,000 and an imprisonment of six months plus a daily fine of $900.
Mr Yeung reiterated that the FEHD would continue to take stringent enforcement actions against these illegal food factories until the situation has improved.
"It is our duty to safeguard public health and environmental hygiene," he added.
"Members of the public are urged not to patronise these illegal premises for the benefit of their own health.
They are also encouraged to report such illegal food business to the Department through our hotline 2868 0000."
19980422_006.e: USD blitz operations against unlicensed food stalls
The following is issued on behalf of the Provisional Urban Council:
The Urban Services Department (USD) has stepped up law enforcement action operations against unlicensable food factories selling cooked food in the urban areas.

A spokesman for the Department said today (Wednesday) that blitz summary arrest operations were launched on both sides of the harbour today against operators of unlicensable food premises, aiming at prosecuting them as soon as possible.
The first round of the operation is expected to be completed in two weeks, he added.
On the first day of operation, a total of 17 operators of unlicensed food factories selling cooked food were arrested, 15 in Mong Kok, one in Wan Chai and one in Aberdeen.

Upon the conviction of the summary arrest case, the spokesman said, the Department may apply to the court for a Prohibition Order under Section 128 of the Public Health and Municipal Services Ordinance against the continued operation of the unlicensed food business.
The maximum penalty for operating unlicensed food businesses is a fine of $50,000, an imprisonment of six months and a daily fine of $900.

Any person who contravenes the Prohibition Order and continues to operate the food business will be prosecuted and is liable to a maximum fine of $100,000, an imprisonment of 12 months plus a daily fine of $1,750.
In a related development, USD executed a Closure Order to physically close down an unlicensed restaurant in Tse Wan Shan.
The restaurant located on the ground floor of Wan Wah Building, 26 Yuk Wah Crescent, Tse Wan Shan had been prosecuted for operating without a licence since September 1994.
Since then, it had a record of 26 convictions and accumulated a total fine of $295,020.
This is the second Closure Order executed by USD within a week since last Friday when an unlicensed restaurant in Kwun Tong was closed down.
The spokesman stressed that to safeguard public health, the Department would not tolerate the operation of unlicensed food businesses and would prosecute the operators.
20000128_012.e: Blitz operations against unlicensed food shops continued
The Food and Environmental Hygiene Department (FEHD) is determined to stem out unlicensed food factories selling snacks and cooked food to ensure public health and environmental hygiene.

The Yau Tsim Mong District Senior Superintendent, Mr Wong Siu-wing said today (Friday): "In view of the increased number of shoppers in the run-up to Lunar New Year, a new round of blitz operations are launched against these unlicensed operators in Mong Kok and Yau Tsim districts.
"In addition to daytime operations, we will also conduct raids in the late evenings to crack down on these illegal food factories.

"Summary arrests will be made against the unlicensed operators while open food exposed to risk of contamination will be seized under Section 59 of the Public Health and Municipal Services Ordinance, Cap 132."

During the first round of raids mounted earlier in Mong Kok, 21 operators were arrested and charged with the offences of operating unlicensed food factories and exposing food to risk of contamination.
In addition, six operators of licensed food premises were summonsed for sale of cooked food exposed to risk of contamination.
A total of 315 kilogrammes of exposed food were seized.
Mr Wong called on members of the public to cooperate with the Department by not patronising these unlicensed food shops for the benefit of their own health.

19990425_009.e: Youths-at-Risk of Substance Abuse and Families of Abusers Given Priority in This Year's Beat Drugs Fund Projects

The Governing Committee of the Beat Drugs Fund, chaired by the Secretary for Security, has approved grants of $6.93 million for 17 anti-drug projects targeting at youths-at-risk and $9.2 million for 11 projects supporting families of drug abusers and families in general, amongst a total of $17.78 million to be granted to 48 projects this year.
In considering this year's applications for the Fund, the Governing Committee attached importance to those aiming to steer youths-at-risk away from drugs.
"We note that the number of drug abusers aged below 21 has been on the decrease in recent years - it dropped by nearly 11 per cent from 3 149 in 1997 to 2 805 in 1998.
Despite this, we recognise that youths-at-risk are a highly vulnerable group and deserve the full attention by all those working in the anti-drug field.

"To prevent our younger generation from abusing drugs, education and publicity is an on-going campaign; and any relaxation in efforts might have adverse consequences," said the Commissioner for Narcotics, Mrs Clarie Lo, who is also a member of the Governing Committee.

Notable amongst the approved projects for youths-at-risk are the $2.5 million proposal to be organised by the Hong Kong Federation of Youth Groups featuring preventive education and guidance for 2 500 high-risk youths from primary and secondary schools, as well as from youth centres in Tsuen Wan and Kwai Tsing districts; and the $2.3 million project by the Hong Kong Christian Service targeting at 3 000 youths-at-risk, including school drop-outs and unemployed young people, with a view to minimising their exposure to social and moral danger which could lead to substance abuse.
Besides youths-at-risk, the Governing Committee recognises that families are also an important target for anti-drug education.

Notable projects supported are the $950,000 programme by the Hong Kong Lutheran Social Services to provide a variety of activities for parents and their children, and the $820,000 programme by Wu Oi Christian Centre for drug abusers and their family members.
Amongst the 48 projects approved this year, 39 are related to drug preventive education and publicity ($12.88 million) and nine to treatment and rehabilitation ($4.9 million).
Amongst the grants for treatment and rehabilitation projects, the biggest one - $1.26 million - went to the Christian New Being Fellowship's project for adolescent drug abusers.

The project aims to lead these abusers to ultimate rehabilitation through participation in high-technology, innovative and productive work so as to develop their work role and work aspiration, which are prerequisites to successful vocational pursuit and re-integration into society.

All the projects have been considered by the Action Committee Against Narcotics (ACAN) and its Sub-committees on Preventive Education and Publicity, Treatment and Rehabilitation, and Research in consultation with the relevant government departments before they were recommended to the Governing Committee for decision.
Meanwhile, members of ACAN and the Sub-committees continue to monitor the progress of the projects financed by the Beat Drugs Fund, and visited two such projects last week.
The members first visited a half-way house operated by Operation Dawn in Prince Edward Road, and saw how it was given a new look following renovation financed by the Beat Drugs Fund.
The party then proceeded to a hostel of the Society for the Rehabilitation of Offenders for a briefing on counselling service for ex-drug abusers.
The Society has employed a peer counsellor to provide the service with grant from the Fund.
Since its establishment in 1996, the Beat Drugs Fund has sponsored a total of 98 projects with $38.53 million in grants.
The number of projects will increase to 146 and fund disbursed to $56.31 million, following this year's allocation.
19990927_011.e: New Initiatives Despite Fall in Number of Reported Drug Abusers
There is a continuing downward trend in the reported numbers of drug abuse cases and young drug abusers in Hong Kong in the first half of 1999.

Speaking at the meeting of the Action Committee Against Narcotics (ACAN) today (Monday), the Commissioner for Narcotics, Mrs Clarie Lo, said, "we are pleased to note that the downward drug abuse trend since 1995 persisted in the first half of 1999".
In this period, a total of 9,928 drug abusers were reported to the Central Registry of Drug Abuse (CRDA), representing a drop of 7.1% from 10,683 persons in the same period last year.
Of the 9,928 drug abusers reported in first half of the year, 1,445 or 14.6% were aged under 21.
This represents a decrease of 17% over the 1,740 young drug abusers in the first half of 1998.
There were also 1,203 female drug abusers reported to the CRDA, representing a drop of 5.7% compared with the corresponding figure in 1998.
The number of newly reported drug abusers in the second quarter this year also fell 11.2% from 856 in the same period last year to 760.

However, reported abusers on ice increased 5% in the first half of 1999 from 504 in the same period last year to 513 while those on Triazolam rose from 368 in the first half of l998 to 405 in the first six months this year, representing a 10.1 percentage point increase.

Mrs Lo attributed the general downward drug abuse trend to the joint efforts by the Government and non-government organisations involved in the anti-drug field, while not losing sight of the increase in the abuse of some kinds of drugs.

"The Government has adopted a five-pronged strategy in combating drug trafficking and abuse, which covers law enforcement, preventive education and publicity, treatment and rehabilitation, research and international co-operation," Mrs Lo said.

Mrs Lo said that the Government will further strengthen its efforts in fighting the drug problems with even greater involvement of the community despite the general falling trend in the number of reported abusers.
With this in mind, ACAN suggested a number of new initiatives.
Amongst them is the establishment of a drug information and exhibition centre to centralise information on drugs and support community involvement programmes in the drug field.
Mrs Lo said that the roof garden at the Queensway Government Offices Low Block would be converted into the exhibition hall of the centre.
Graphic displays, replicas of drugs and interactive exhibits will be featured.
There will also be thematic displays which are changed periodically, displays on topical issues relating to drug abuse and forthcoming anti-drug programmes.
ACAN also recommended other measures to enhance partnership with the community on anti-drug work.
The Youth Volunteer Group of ACAN will be revamped to attract more volunteers from different sectors of society, and work of the group will be more diversified.
On drug treatment and rehabilitation, the roadmap for the next three years is being drawn up in consultation with the agencies in the drug field.
The plan will examine the present provision of drug treatment and rehabilitation facilities and services in Hong Kong, and will guide future plans in this area.
The plan is also tied to the current review of Methadone Treatment Programme, the largest voluntary programme subscribed by opiate drug abusers so far.
The objectives, scope and effectiveness of the programme are now being vigorously reviewed.
Possible clinical trials of new drugs in detoxification and relapse prevention will be considered in the review.

Reflecting on the experience of the ACAN visit to Singapore in June this year, members considered that the objective of enhancing cross-fertilization of ideas and exchanges of information between Hong Kong and Singapore on anti-drug work had been well achieved.
ACAN is in fact applying references to Singapore's naltrexone trial, partnership programmes and volunteer programmes actively.
19980430_016.e: Registration of non-medical detoxification centres proposed
The Government will tomorrow (Friday) launch a public consultation exercise on a proposed registration scheme for non-medical drug treatment and rehabilitation centres.
The consultation will last until 30 June 1998.

The Commissioner for Narcotics, Mrs Clarie Lo, explained that existing drug treatment and rehabilitation centres which provide medical detoxification are registered as nursing homes by the Department of Health under the Hospitals, Nursing Homes and Maternity Homes Ordinance (Cap.165).

The regulatory controls imposed on these medical drug treatment and rehabilitation centres as nursing homes include, among others, the accommodation, staffing and equipment used or to be used in such centres which should be fit for the purposes intended.
However, centres which adopt a non-medical approach in the treatment and rehabilitation of drug abusers are not subject to any registration control.
"There are about 11 non-medical drug treatment and rehabilitation centres in Hong Kong.
It is observed that most of them are accommodated in stone or wooden huts in remote areas.
Some of them are also not fitted with proper electricity and water supplies.
Thus, they would be subject to building, fire safety or environmental health risks should accidents happen," Mrs Lo said.
"The management and operation of such centres also vary," she added.

Taking into account these observations, the Government proposes and the Action Committee Against Narcotics supports that a registration scheme should be introduced for non-medical drug treatment and rehabilitation centres, in order to:
* ensure drug patients undergo treatment and rehabilitation in a properly managed and secure environment to safeguard their well-being;

* protect the rights and welfare of drug patients who, like other drug patients in medical drug treatment and rehabilitation centres, are subject to psychological stress and physical health problems when undergoing treatment and rehabilitation.
The staff and treatment approaches adopted by these centres should, therefore, be competent/relevant in providing services to them; and
* enable the Government to keep a register of the non-medical drug treatment and rehabilitation centres and to impose requirements and standards for their operations as necessary.

To ensure broadly the same registration standards to be applied to all drug treatment and rehabilitation centres, Mrs Lo said the proposed registration requirements to be introduced for non-medical drug treatment and rehabilitation centres would be similar to those provisions of Cap.165 which currently apply to medical drug treatment and rehabilitation centres.
The major registration requirements will include the following:

* a person in charge of a drug treatment and rehabilitation centre will need to apply to an authority for registration if the centre provides residential care, treatment and rehabilitation service for drug abusers;

* registration of an applicant is subject to the conditions that the drug treatment and rehabilitation centre under application complies with fire safety and building safety requirements as prescribed by the Director of Fire Services and the Director of Buildings respectively (the preliminary requirements have been set out in the consultation document); and
* the applicant is fit for operating a drug treatment and rehabilitation centre.
(A definition of 'fitness' has been included in the consultation document).

Failure to comply with the registration requirements or operating a drug treatment and rehabilitation centre without a registration certificate will be liable to a fine of $1,000 and/or imprisonment for three months.
The registration scheme for non-medical drug treatment and rehabilitation centres will be implemented in phases.
"We consider it not practical to require all of them to be registered at once since most of them will need substantial physical upgrading to meet the proposed registration requirements.

In this respect, they are, no matter subvented or non-subvented, welcomed to apply to the Lotteries Fund for upgrading their facilities or accommodation to meet the necessary requirements," Mrs Lo said.
The first phase of the registration scheme will cover those non-medical drug treatment and rehabilitation centres which receive subvention from the Social Welfare Department.
Other non-medical drug treatment and rehabilitation centres will be covered in a subsequent phase as some of them might wish to seek other sources of funding.

As regards the registration procedures, Mrs Lo said all operators of non-medical drug treatment and rehabilitation centres would be required to notify the registration authority of their operation within three months after commencement of the enabling legislation.
They will be granted exemption certificates which will provisionally exempt them from registration until such certificates are revoked.
For these non-medical drug treatment and rehabilitation centres covered in the first phase, their exemption certificates will be revoked 48 months after the end of the notification period.
During this grace period, they are encouraged to obtain a registration certificate from the registration authority as soon as they are ready.
If they fail to obtain a registration certificate by the end of the grace period, they will have to cease operation.

As regards those non-medical drug treatment and rehabilitation centres set up upon or after the commencement of the enabling legislation, the operator will need to apply for registration before starting to provide such services.
Non-medical drug treatment and rehabilitation centres not covered in the first phase will also be granted exemption certificates.
The timing of implementation of the registration scheme for them will be decided in the light of experience gained as these centres have their unique circumstances.
"The registration authority for non-medical drug treatment and rehabilitation centres will be the Social Welfare Department.

A new piece of legislation will be proposed to empower the Department, as the registration authority, to register an applicant in respect of non-medical drug treatment and rehabilitation centres and to enforce the requirements of the registration scheme," Mrs Lo said.
Any views on the registration scheme will be carefully considered by the Government before putting forward the legislation on the proposed registration scheme.
Comments may be sent in writing to the Narcotics Division, 23rd floor, High Block, Queensway Government Offices, 66 Queensway, before June 30, 1998.
Copies of the public consultation paper on the proposed registration scheme are available at the Narcotics Division and the District Offices.
The consultation paper can also be viewed on the Narcotics Division's Homepage at www.info.gov.hk/nd/.
20000408_011.e: Beat Drugs Fund Grants $16 million in Support of 29 Anti-Drug Projects
The Governing Committee of the Beat Drugs Fund, chaired by the Secretary for Security, has approved grants of $16.39 million for 29 anti-drug projects this year.

The Commissioner for Narcotics, Mrs Clarie Lo, who is also a member of the Governing Committee, said, "The number of drug abusers aged below 21 dropped by 13.6 per cent from 2829 in 1998 to 2 443 in 1999.
Despite the continuing drop in recent years, we recognise that youths-at-risk are a highly vulnerable group and deserve the full attention of all those working in the anti-drug field."
"To prevent our younger generation from abusing drugs, education and publicity is an on-going campaign; and any relaxation in efforts might have adverse consequences," Mrs Lo added.
In considering this year's applications for the Fund, the Governing Committee attached importance to those aiming to steer youths-at-risk away from drugs.

Amongst the 29 projects approved this year, 22 are related to drug prevention education and publicity ($10.72 million), five to treatment and rehabilitation ($2.98 million)and two to research ($2.69 million).
An amount of $2.08 million was granted to conduct a pioneering longitudinal research on the development and validation of a drug prevention programme in Hong Kong.
Youths-at-risk aged between 10 to 15 in selected areas including Tuen Mun and Kwun Tong will be invited to take part in the project.
Participants will be taught on the adverse effect of drug abuse, social and personal skills to help them identify and resist peer influence to use drugs.
Parents, teachers and community leaders will be involved in helping the participants.
Evaluation will be made at the end of the project to trace the change in attitude towards drugs among these youths.
"This is the first research project to be funded by the Beat Drugs Fund.
The study will be useful in developing a package of drug preventive programmes for anti-drug workers in Hong Kong," Mrs Lo said.
Another project targeting at youths-at-risk is a "Mentoring Program" which involves parents, teachers and volunteers in steering young drug abusers away from drugs.
Amongst the treatment and rehabilitation related projects, $1 million was granted to a project called "Art Therapy Treatment Programme" run by an anti-drug worker in the medical field.
The project aims to promote a new treatment method for drug addiction.
Under this project, more services for drug addicts and their family members and training for anti-drug workers and volunteers will be provided.

All the projects have been considered by the Action Committee Against Narcotics (ACAN) and its Sub-committees on Preventive Education and Publicity, Treatment and Rehabilitation, and Research in consultation with the relevant government departments before they were recommended to the Governing Committee for decision.
Since its establishment in 1996, the Beat Drugs Fund has sponsored a total of 145 projects with $56.72 million in grants.
The number of projects will increase to 174 and fund disbursed to $73.11 million, following this year's allocation.
19990218_009.e: Drug Treatment Centres Registration Scheme will be Introduced

The Government intends to introduce a scheme to make it a statutory requirement for a person to apply to the Director of Social Welfare for registration, if he intends to operate an establishment providing voluntary residential care, treatment and rehabilitation services for four or more drug abusers.
The scheme has been supported by the Legco Panel on Security.

The Commissioner for Narcotics, Mrs Clarie Lo, said the main purpose of the scheme is to improve the standard of drug treatment and rehabilitation services and to ensure that patients will receive such services in a properly managed and secure physical environment.

The scheme will also impose uniform control on drug treatment and rehabilitation centres, thus removing the apparent policy inconsistency that centres currently providing voluntary residential medical detoxification and rehabilitation services are subject to statutory control, while centres providing similar services except medical detoxification are not subject to any control.
To register, a centre must comply with the requirements of building services and fire safety as stipulated by the Buildings and Fire Services Departments respectively.

The applicant must also fulfil the "fit" person criteria, which will stipulate that in the ten years prior to registration, the applicant must not have undergone any drug treatment programme and committed any serious offence, including drug offences, such as manufacturing, trafficking and possession.
Mrs Lo said that the registration scheme "will not seek to impose too much control on the services currently provided by drug treatment and rehabilitation centres.
The licensing authority will ensure that the centres will continue to enjoy the autonomy of staff employment within the limits of current guidelines applicable to them."
The scheme will affect 13 existing agencies which operate 40 treatment and rehabilitation centres, including half-way houses providing residential care services to drug abusers.
"The registration scheme will be implemented in two phases.
Phase I will only affect the drug treatment and rehabilitation centres currently subvented by the Government.
They will be given a grace of period of four years to prepare for registration.
"Phase II will affect the centres which are not subvented by the Government", said Mrs Lo.

"The Narcotics Division has been liaising with various charitable funds to alert them of the possible demand from these centres for funding the upgrading works in order to meet the registration requirements", she added.
The proposal of the registration scheme was put to public consultation from May to October 1998.
All views collected were in support of the proposal.

The Government will proceed with the drafting of the enabling legislation for the registration scheme in the remainder of 1999, with a view to introducing the Bill to the Legislative Council in its next session.

Subject to the passage of the enabling legislation which will replace the existing Drug Addicts Treatment and Rehabilitation Ordinance (Cap 326), it is expected that the scheme will come into operation in the latter half of 2000.
19990829_012.e: Research on Treatment Strategies for Drug Abusers Commissioned
The Action Committee Against Narcotics (ACAN) Research Sub-committee has decided to commission two major research on treatment and rehabilitation for drug abusers in Hong Kong in 1999.
The Research Sub-committee invites research proposals from tertiary institutions, non-government organizations and government departments on a yearly basis.
The objective of such research is to assist the Government and ACAN to study various aspects relating to drug abuse for the formulation of anti-drug policies and programmes.
The first research project endorsed by the Research Sub-committee in 1999 is an in-depth study on the chronic drug abusers, and methadone patients in particular.

The study was commissioned to The Chinese University of Hong Kong, and aims to find out the underlying causes for the chronic abuse of illicit drugs and the relapse into drug addiction after detoxification and rehabilitation.

Commenting on the research topic, a spokesman of the Narcotics Division said, "It is considered that there is a demonstrated need for such a project, as relapse into drug addiction following detoxification and rehabilitation has been an issue of great concern for policy-makers and workers in the anti-drug field."

"It is hoped that the findings of the study will help the Government and ACAN develop effective treatment strategies for chronic or frequently relapsed drug abusers, and look into what modifications should be made to the existing methadone programme.
"Among the reported cases in the Central Registry of Drug Abuse, over 75% of them are old cases and more than half of them are cases from methadone treatment programme.
"This coincide with the observation that relapse is an acute problem for those who have a long drug addiction history, in particular methadone patients," he added.
The research costs about $1 million and is expected to take three years to complete.
The second research project, commissioned to the Kwai Chung Hospital and The Chinese University of Hong Kong, is a study on the motivational strategy for engaging early drug abusers for treatment.
The study aims to assess the current methods of persuading drug abusers, especially early drug abusers, to seek treatment and to evaluate the effectiveness of motivational strategy.

"It is recognized in psychiatric field that, drug abuse cases which are identified early usually stand a better chance of recovering in full, while late ones normally have more severe or perhaps life-long psychiatric damage," the spokesman said.
"Therefore, it is considered that more efforts should be made to persuade early drug abusers to seek treatment.
"The findings of the study are expected to cast light on how to motivate more drug abusers to come forward for treatment," he added.
The project costs about $300,000 and will take one year to complete.
In 1998, the Research Sub-committee had commissioned 10 studies, among which two have been completed, and 8 are still in progress.
In the 1998/99 financial year, the Government devoted a total of $8.3 million to drug research-related work.
19980306_007.e: Number of reported drug abusers dropped in 1997

The number of drug abusers reported to the Central Registry of Drug Abuse (CRDA) in 1997 totalled 17,555, a drop of 10.8 per cent over the 19,671 reported in 1996, according to CRDA statistics presented to the Action Committee Against Narcotics (ACAN) today (Friday).
Speaking at ACAN's quarterly meeting, the Commissioner for Narcotics, Mrs Clarie Lo, said that young drug abusers reported in 1997 had also dropped by 14.3 per cent compared with 1996.
"A total of 3,135 drug abusers aged below 21 were reported in 1997 as compared with 3,656 in 1996."
Mrs Lo pointed out that CRDA statistics showed that the overall number of reported drug abusers dropped in 1997.
"In 1994, we had 20,327 reported drug abusers of all ages, and 4,289 drug abusers aged below 21.
The figures dropped to 17,555 and 3,135 respectively in 1997," she said.
She went on to say that more encouraging was the fact that the number of reported drug abusers aged below 21 had also decreased since 1994.
"In 1994, there were 4,289 reported young drug abusers, but the figure dropped to 3,988 in 1995, 3,656 in 1996 and 3,135 in 1997."
However, CRDA statistics showed that the reported number of psychotropic substances abusers appeared to be on the rise, she added.
"There were 3,451 reported psychotropic substance abusers of all ages in 1997, compared with 3,388 in 1996 and 2,618 in 1995.
As regards psychotropic substance abusers aged below 21, 1,269 abusers were reported in 1997, compared with 1,357 in 1996."
Mrs Lo pointed out that there was a small decrease in the number of female drug abusers in 1997 when 2,216 abusers were reported, compared with 2,429 in 1996.

ACAN noted that the downward drug abuse trend in 1997 was consistent with the downward movement of drug-related factors such as reported crimes, persons receiving treatment and admissions to drug treatment agencies.

Notwithstanding this observation, a thorough study on factors affecting the drug abuse trend in Hong Kong was recently commissioned by ACAN with a view to identifying the underlying factors that affect the size, complexity and characteristics of the drug abuse population in Hong Kong.
The study will be completed by 2000.
On preventive education, Mrs Lo said that more resources would be devoted to stepping up the beat drugs campaign despite the drop in the number of drug abusers figures.
She said that ACAN's Preventive Education and Publicity Sub-committee had adopted the following themes for education and publicity programmes for 1998/99:
(i) to heighten awareness of the undesirable consequences of abusing drugs, no matter 'hard' or 'soft';";
(ii) to educate the public, in particular young people, that drug abuse is not the solution to any problem, and to equip them with life skills; and
(iii) to emphasise the positive effects of staying drug-free.
"The budget for the 1998/99 preventive education and publicity programmes amounted to about $5.1 million," Mrs Lo said.
Within that budget, $1.3 million will be used for updating videos for anti-drug education talks for secondary and primary 6 students, and producing a new video for a new talk for primary 5 students.

A sum of about $1 million had been budgeted for producing publicity programmes through the electronic media; printing publicity posters and leaflets; and placing advertisement on television, radio, buses and MTR stations.

In addition, $2.86 million have been earmarked for organising various preventive education programmes and subsiding District Fight Crime Committees, District School Liaison Committees and community organisations in carrying out anti-drugs publicity activities.

ACAN was also informed by a Social Welfare Department's representative at the meeting that the Subventions and Lotteries Fund Advisory Committee had supported the Government to grant $16.12 million to subvent the services provided by four non-medical voluntary drug treatment and rehabilitation agencies for the 1998/99 financial year.

The four agencies are the Barnabas Charitable Service Association, the Christian New Being Fellowship, the Finnish Missionary Service Ling Oi Youth Centre and the Operation Dawn, all of which will also be granted a total subvention of $1.26 million to cover their expenses for the month of March in the 1997/98 financial year.

The decision on subventions followed a government evaluation study of the services provided by non-medical drug treatment and rehabilitation agencies with a view to including them in the subvention system.
