19990802_006.e: Anti-drug work poses challenge

One of the major challenges facing the world is trafficking in illicit drugs and related organised crimes, said the Commissioner for Narcotics, Mrs Clarie Lo, at a major conference on drug dependence today (Monday).

Speaking at the opening of "1999 Hong Kong and Mainland Conference on Drug Dependence" at the Chinese University of Hong Kong, Mrs Lo added: "New technology not only has shortened distance, but also greatly increased production of synthetic drugs and enabled them to be transported from one place to another.
Drug syndicates have become increasingly internationalized and their operations increasingly complicated.
As a result, the challenges facing governments over the world are getting bigger and bigger."
Briefly introducing the present drug abuse situation in Hong Kong, Mrs Lo said the number of reported drug abusers had been on the decrease since 1995.
There were about 16 000 reported drug abusers in 1998, and 5 527 in the first quarter of 1999, representing a drop of 11 per cent compared with the same period in 1998.

Hong Kong adopted a multi-proned approach in combating the problems of drug trafficking and drug abuse through law enforcement, international co-operation, treatment and rehabilitation, preventive education and publicity, as well as research, Mrs Lo continued.

In law enforcement, Hong Kong had enacted sound legislation to control the supply, manufacture and storage of dangerous drugs and psychotropic substances, and to prevent chemicals from being used for manufacturing dangerous drugs.

The Drug Trafficking (Recovery of Proceeds) Ordinance enabled the Government to trace, freeze and confiscate drug traffickers' drug proceeds, and spelt out various measures to combat money laundering activities.
The Organised and Serious Crimes Ordinance was being amended to require money changers and remittance agents to take anti-money laundering measures.
Mrs Lo pointed out that Hong Kong adopted a multi-modality approach for treatment and rehabilitation to meet the needs of drug abusers with different backgrounds.
"This year, we'll propose legislation to require treatment and rehabilitation centres providing voluntary residential services to register in order to raise the standard of their services.
We are currently reviewing the success of the methadone treatment programme.
In the review, we'll explore the feasibility of supplementing or replacing methadone with other drugs," she added.

Looking ahead, Mrs Lo said that posing a challenge to anti-drug work would be the crisis to be brought about by mass production of synthetic drugs, youngsters abusing psychotropic substances at places of public entertainment and other places,as well as the problems of female drug abusers.

Officiating at the opening of the conference, the Hon Dr Rosanna Wong, Member of the Executive Council, said that strengthening liaison and exchanges in anti-drug work between Hong Kong and the Mainland was essential to the long term co-operation in tackling drug problems.

"I believe that anti-drug work and latest developments in the Mainland and Hong Kong can be explored in depth at this conference, and can benefit from your experience for further improvement to existing services and measures," she told the participants.

Over 200 anti-drug policy administrators, law enforcers, academics and professionals all over China attended the five-day conference, which is the first of its nature and scale held in Hong Kong after the Handover.

Participants from China include Mr Yin Dakui, Vice-Minister, Ministry of Health; Mr Shao Mingli, Deputy Secretary General, State Drug Administration; and Mr Wang Kang, Deputy Secretary General, National Narcotics Control Commission.
Organised by the Department of Psychiatry of the Chinese University of Hong Kong, the conference features the main theme of "Challenges and Opportunities: Multi-Modality Approach in Substance Abuse".
The conference was financed with grants from the Beat Drugs Fund.
Since its establishment in 1996, the fund has financed 145 anti-drug projects with grants of $55.16 million.
19990729_008.e: ACAN Members Find Singapore Visit Fruitful

The Action Committee Against Narcotics (ACAN) will consider the recommendations made by its members who paid a fact-finding visit to witness Singapore's anti-drug policies and strategies in action last month.

A delegation of 17 unofficial members of ACAN and its three sub-committees, accompanied by five officials from Department of Health, Social Welfare Department and Narcotics Division, spent four days in Singapore, studying how Singapore tackles its drug abuse problems through legislation, law enforcement, preventive education, treatment and rehabilitation, as well as aftercare services.

The delegation had exchanged with members of the National Council Against Drug Abuse (NCADA), Singapore's counterpart of ACAN and officials from the Ministry of Home Affairs, the Central Narcotics Bureau and the Prisons Department.

It had also visited various voluntary organisations in the drug field, and private companies which are taking part in a partnership programme with the Singapore Government on drug preventive education.
ACAN Chairman, Professor Lee Shiu-hung, who led the delegation, said members observed that the trip had been useful especially in strengthening international cooperation in the anti-drug area.
In preventive education and publicity, members were impressed by the Partnership Programme for a Drug-free Singapore.

They also reaffirmed the present direction taken by the Narcotics Division in actively involving the community in anti-drug work, and proposed that the Division should align the community more closely, e.g. by inviting advertising companies and the media to contribute to large-scale anti-drug campaigns.
Members considered that involving volunteers in spreading anti-drug message was one of the best ways to involve the community.

In this regard, Prof. Lee pointed out that the Action Committee Against Narcotics was revamping the Youth Volunteer Group, and would encourage people from different sectors to contribute to anti-drug work.

Noting Singapore's badge scheme to encourage students to spread anti-drug messages, members have recommended that the Narcotics Division should consider a similar scheme to pay recognition to students who made significant contribution to the anti-drug cause.
For treatment and rehabilitation, members recommended that cross referral between various modalities in Hong Kong should be strengthened.

Given the Singapore experience in using "naltrexone" in relapse prevention, members suggested that it might be worthwhile for Hong Kong to consider the possibility of launching clinical trial using naltrexone as well as other new drugs in the context of the methadone treatment programme review.

Referring to Singapore's aftercare programmes of helping drug addicts to find jobs, members have suggested introducing similar programmes in Hong Kong to strengthen vocational training for drug addicts.
They also recommended giving employers some incentives to employ ex-addicts to help the latter reintegrate in the society.

In conclusion, members suggested that, due to social and political differences between Singapore and Hong Kong, not all Singapore anti-drug policies and strategies can be directly transplanted to Hong Kong.
However, the visit was fruitful and stimulating, and was very beneficial for future planning of anti-narcotic policies in Hong Kong.

19990120_017.e: Seizure of dutiable cigarettes by Customs
Customs officers yesterday (Tuesday) smashed a distribution centre of contraband cigarettes in San Po Kong following the seizure of 1.36 million dutiable cigarettes.
The seized goods carried a market value of $1.78 million and a duty potential of $1.05 million.
"This was the second significant seizure of dutiable cigarettes effected by the Department in the past five days.
The first case involved the seizure of 9.58 million cigarettes in Kwai Chung Container Terminal last Friday (January 15)," said a spokesman for the Customs and Excise Department.
Following intensive investigations, Customs officers of Anti-Cigarette-Smuggling Task Force yesterday raided an industrial unit in San Po Kong.
As a result, they made the seizure and arrested two men, including an overstayer from the Mainland.
The arrested, aged 27 and 42, will be jointly charged with "Dealing with goods to which the Dutiable Commodities Ordinance applies" under the Dutiable Commodities Ordinance.
The maximum penalty for the offence is a fine of $1 million and imprisonment for two years.
"The Department will continue its vigorous enforcement actions to check the supply of dutiable cigarettes to show the determination in protecting public revenue," the spokesman added.
20000210_008.e: Customs operation against sale of illicit cigarettes

Customs officers from the Marine and Land Enforcement (MLE) Division today (Thursday) seized about 100,000 sticks of dutiable cigarettes, which carried a market value of about $150,000 and a duty potential of about $80,000, in an operation against the sale of dutiable cigarettes at street level in Mong Kok.
During the operation, the officers arrested two men and a woman, including a buyer.

At about 10:30 am today, Customs officers arrested a man and a Vietnamese woman at the junction of Nelson Street and Canton Road in connection with the seizure of about 20,000 sticks of dutiable cigarettes.
The officers also seized another 20,000 sticks of dutiable cigarettes in the vicinity.
About 15 minutes later, Customs officers saw a man moving six cartons at 377 New Reclamation Street.
The officers immediately intercepted the man and seized about 60,000 sticks of duty-not-paid cigarettes at the staircases between the second and third floor.
The arrested, aged between 28 and 33, will be charged with offences in relation with "dealing with goods to which dutiable commodities apply" and "sale and purchase of dutiable goods".
According to the Ordinance, the maximum penalty for the offence is a fine of $1 million and two years'imprisonment.
In 1999, Customs officers conducted 115 successfully raids in Mong Kok in which 61 people, including 16 buyers, were arrested.
Over 3.1 million sticks of duty-not-paid cigarettes were seized.

A spokesman for the Customs and Excise Department appealed to the public not to buy illicit cigarettes as both the buyer and seller will face a criminal charge under the Dutiable Commodities Ordinance.
Anyone arrested in connection with the offence will be fingerprinted, the spokesman warned.
The spokesman stressed that the Department would continue taking stringent enforcement actions against illicit cigarette activities.
Last year, officers from the MLE seized about 32 million sticks of dutiable cigarettes and arrested 1,459 people, including 161 buyers, in connection with the sale of dutiable cigarettes.
He also appealed to members of the public to provide information on illicit cigarette activities through the Customs 24-hour hotline 2545 6182.
19990819_003.e: Seizure of dutiable cigarettes by Customs

Customs officers smashed a dutiable cigarettes packaging and storage centre in Sham Shui Po following the seizure of 650,000 sticks of dutiable cigarettes worth about $1 million, and a duty potential of about $500,000 today (Thursday).
At about 12:30pm today, Customs Officers of the Marine and Land Enforcement Command saw a large quantity of cartons being moved outside a premise of a building in Ki Lung Street.
The officers later arrested a woman and seized 650,000 sticks of dutiable cigarettes and some packaging equipment.
The 38-year-old woman, will be charged under the Dutiable Commodities Ordinance.
The maximum penalty for the offence is a fine of $1 million and imprisonment of two years.
"The Department will continue its vigorous enforcement actions to check the supply of dutiable cigarettes to show the determination in protecting public revenue," the spokesman stressed.
19990422_009.e: Customs operation against sale of illicit cigarettes

Customs officers today (Thursday) seized over 150,000 sticks of dutiable cigarettes, which carried a market value of about $210,000 and a duty potential of $116,000, in a territory-wide operation against sale of illicit cigarettes.

During the operation codenamed "Operation Torpedo", lasting for 10 hours from 6 am, officers from the Customs Marine and Land Enforcement Command raided the black spots selling dutiable cigarettes throughout Hong Kong.
As a result, they made the seizure and arrested 11 men and five women, aged between 22 and 68.
The arrested will be charged with offences in relation with "dealing with goods to which dutiable commodities apply", and "sale of dutiable goods".
According to the Dutiable Commodities Ordinance, the maximum penalty for the offence is a fine of $1 million and two years' imprisonment.
A spokesman for the Customs and Excise Department warned the public not to buy illicit cigarettes as both the buyer and seller will face the same charge if they are arrested for the offence.
The spokesman said the Department would continue taking stringent enforcement actions against illicit cigarette activities.
The spokesman also appealed to members of the public to provide more information on illicit cigarette activities through the Customs 24-hour hotline 2545 6182.
19980910_009.e: Seizure of dutiable cigarettes by Customs
Customs officers yesterday (Wednesday) seized 200,000 sticks of smuggled cigarettes and arrested 16 suspects in a territory wide anti-cigarette-smuggling operation.
The value of the seizure is about $270,000, with a duty potential of $150,000.
During the operation code-named "Tornado 105", officers from the Customs Marine and Land Enforcement Command raided several black spots of selling smuggled cigarettes and made the seizure.
The arrested, aged between 23 and 58, have been charged with "dealing with goods to which Dutiable Commodities Ordinance applies".

"Any person found committing the offence, including dealing, selling or purchasing dutiable commodities, will be subject to a maximum penalty of $1 million fine and two years' imprisonment," said a spokesman for the Customs and Excise Department.
The department would continue their anti-cigarette-smuggling operations to smash distribution centres of contraband cigarettes, he added.
19990409_015.e: Seizure of dutiable cigarettes by Customs
Customs officers yesterday (Thursday) seized 1.75 million sticks of dutiable cigarettes, which carried a market value of $2.3 million and a duty potential of $1.3 million, in Tai Po.
Acting on intelligence, Customs Officers of the Anti-cigarettes Smuggling Task Force raided a premises in Tai Po, believed to be a distribution centre of contraband cigarettes.
As a result, they made the seizure and arrested a 22-year-old man and a 45-year-old woman.
"The dutiable cigarettes for distribution to retail outlets in Sha Tin and most in Kowloon," said a spokesman for the Customs and Excise Department.
The arrested persons have been charged under the Dutiable Commodities Ordinance.
The maximum penalty for the offence is a fine of $1 million and imprisonment of two years.
"The Department will continue its vigorous enforcement actions to check the supply of dutiable cigarettes to show the determination in protecting public revenue," the spokesman stressed.
19990804_008.e: Customs operation against sale of illicit cigarettes

A spokesman for the Customs and Excise Department today (Wednesday) warned the public not to buy illicit cigarettes as both the buyer and seller will face a criminal charge under the Dutiable Commodities Ordinance.
According to the Ordinance, the maximum penalty for the offence is a fine of $1 million and two years' imprisonment.

Customs officer today seized 58,000 sticks of dutiable cigarettes, which carried a market value of about $80,000 and a duty potential of $44,700, in a territory-wide operation against sale of illicit cigarettes in streets.
During the operation, officers from the Customs Marine and Land Enforcement Command raided black spots selling dutiable cigarettes throughout Hong Kong.
As a result, they made the seizure and arrested 12 men and six women, including 10 buyers.
The arrested, aged between 17 and 82, will be charged with offences in relation with "dealing with goods to which dutiable commodities apply" and "sale of dutiable goods".
The spokesman said the Department would continue taking stringent enforcement actions against illicit cigarette activities.
He also appeal to members of the public to provide more information on illicit cigarette activities through the Customs 24-hour hotline 2545 6182.
19990830_015.e: Seizure of dutiable cigarettes by Customs

Speedy action by Customs officers led to the seizure of more than 1.1 million sticks of dutiable cigarettes, which carried a market value of $1.45 million, and a duty potential of about $890,000, in the new Territories last Thursday (August 26).
Acting on self-developed investigations, Customs Officers of the Marine and Land Enforcement Command intercepted three light goods vehicles at a Yuen Long carpark at about 12:50 pm on that day.
As a result, they arrested a 21-year-old man and seized 850,000 contraband cigarettes from three vehicles.
Acting on follow-up enquiries, Customs Officers made a further seizure of 310,000 sticks of dutiable cigarettes, at an open space in Shek Kong about three hours later.
The suspect has been charged with related offences and will appear in Tuen Mun Court on September 24.
"Anyone found in breach of the Dutiable Commodities Ordinance is liable to a maximum fine of$1 million and imprisonment of two years," said a spokesman for the Customs and Excise Department.
"The Department will continue its vigorous enforcement actions to check the supply of dutiable cigarettes to show the determination in protecting public revenue," the spokesman stressed.
Meanwhile, the Customs appealed for information on smuggling of cigarettes.
Information could be passed to the Customs hotline 2545 6182.
20000302_005.e: Customs officers today(Thursday)smashed two dutiable cigarettes distribution and storage centres in Tsuen Wan and Fanling and seized about a total of 5.1 million sticks of dutiable cigarettes.
The seizures carried a market value of about $5.6 million and a duty potential of $3.3 million.

After intensive analysis of information and investigation, at about 8 am today, a team of watchful Customs officers of the Anti-Cigarette-Smuggling Task Force raided a unit in an industrial building in Tsuen Wan and seized about 4.3 million sticks of dutiable cigarettes from the premises.
During the operation, four Mainland men, aged between 30 and 40, were arrested by the officers.
They will be charged with "Dealing with goods to which Dutiable Commodities Ordinance applies" under the Dutiable Commodities Ordinance.
According to the Dutiable Commodities Ordinance, the maximum penalty is a fine of $1 million and imprisonment of two years.

"We believed the arrested persons are responsible for distributing contraband cigarettes to retail outlets in the West Kowloon and the New Territories," said a spokesman of the Customs and Excise Department.
In a seperate case, at about 11 am today, a team of Anti-Cigarette-Smuggling Task Force, raided a hut in Fanling and seized about 800,000 sticks of dutiable cigarettes.

"Apart from strengthening the collection of intelligence on any possible smuggling activities, Customs officers have also been maintaining vigilant enforcement actions to tackle the problem," he added.
20000426_012.e: Vigorous enforcement actions against illicit cigarette activities
The Customs Anti-Illicit Cigarette Task Force (CTF) established this month will be stepping up enforcement actions against illicit cigarette activities both at the supply and retail level.

At the retail level, members of the CTF and Customs officers from the Marine and Land Enforcement Command, more than 50 officers, conducted a joint operation today, aimed at cracking down illicit cigarette activities at street level.

During the 12-hour operation starting from 6 am, in 13 cases the officers seized about 58,000 sticks of dutiable cigarettes, which carried a market value of $80,000, and a duty potential of $45,000, after raiding various blackspots in the territory selling illicit cigarettes.
Seven men and two women, including two buyers, were arrested.
The arrested, aged between 20 and 67, will be charged with offences in relation with "dealing with goods to which dutiable commodities apply" and "sale and purchase of dutiable goods".

In a seperate case, Customs officers of the CTF this morning smashed a dutiable cigarettes storage and distribution centre in Ping Che, Fanling, following the seizure of 660,000 sticks of dutiable cigarettes, which carried a market value of $900,000 and a duty potential of about $500,000.
After intensive investigations, a team of watchful Customs officers raided a unit in a tin-sheeted hut in Fanling at about 10 am, and seized the dutiable cigarettes and impounded a lorry.
During the operation, two men, aged 31 and 34, were arrested by the officers.
They will be charged with "Dealing with goods to which Dutiable Commodities Ordinance applies" under the Dutiable Commodities Ordinance.

"Apart from strengthening the collection of intelligence on any possible smuggling activities, Customs officers have also been maintaining vigilant enforcement actions to tackle the problem," said a spokesman for the Department.
The spokesman also appealed to members of the public not to buy illicit cigarettes as both the buyer or seller will face a criminal charge under the Dutiable Commodities Ordinance.
According to the Ordinance, the maximum penalty for the offence is a fine of $1 million and two years' imprisonment.

20000402_012.e: Chief Executive touches down in Toronto for Canada visit
The Chief Executive, Mr Tung Chee Hwa, has today (April 2, HK time) touched down in Toronto for a four-day official visit to Canada.
Mr Tung was greeted by China's Ambassador to Canada, Mr Mei Ping, China's Acting Consul General in Toronto, Mr Li Shiqi and Canada's Consul General in Hong Kong, Mr Colin Russel.

During the visit, Mr Tung will brief political and business leaders on Hong Kong's economic recovery, its development as a technology and innovation hub, opportunities arising in Hong Kong from China's accession to the World Trade Organisation (WTO) and the long-term strategy to position Hong Kong as Asia's most cosmopolitan and dynamic 'World City'.

The Chief Executive will highlight business opportunities for Canadian companies in Hong Kong, especially in the environmental and technology fields, and speak on the successful implementation of 'One Country, Two Systems'.
"I am here basically to renew old acquaintances and make new friends," said Mr Tung.

"I will also be explaining how well Hong Kong has been doing in the two-and-a-half years since Reunification, how well we have implemented 'One Country, Two Systems' and how well our economy is now recovering.
"I will also point out to our Canadian friends the vast opportunities of commerce and trade in the Asia-Pacific Region and the increased opportunities when China becomes a member of the WTO.
"Hong Kong is uniquely positioned to help Canadian businesses expand in these areas, so I am very much looking forward to my visit."
Mr Tung said that Canadian companies were particularly strong in the technology and environmental industries.
"We would welcome their participation in developing these industries in Hong Kong," he said.
On Monday, Mr Tung flies to the Canadian capital Ottawa for meetings with Prime Minister Jean Chretien, Foreign Minister Lloyd Axworthy and Finance Minister Paul Martin.
Mr Tung will also hold talks with the Canada-Hong Kong Parliamentary Friendship Group and attend a briefing and demonstration at a high-tech company.

On Tuesday, Mr Tung returns to Toronto where he will deliver two keynote speeches - a luncheon address to more than 800 business, political, academic and Chinese community leaders and a dinner function to be attended by about 200 of Canada's top corporate executives.
Mr Tung is also due to meet Toronto Mayor Mel Lastman and receive a briefing on environmental issues by state and local government officials.
Photo: The Chief Executive, Mr Tung Chee Hwa, and Mrs Tung are greeted by China's Ambassador to Canada, Mr Mei Ping, and his wife Mei Lin Sa, after arriving in Toronto.
19990926_013.e: The Chief Executive, Mr Tung Chee Hwa, has left for Shanghai today (Sunday) to attend the 1999 Fortune Global Forum.
"Mr Tung will participate in the Forum as a member of the VIP delegation of the Central People's Government," a Government spokesman said.
While in Shanghai, Mr Tung will attend the welcome reception and the gala dinner of the Forum to be held tomorrow evening.
The Chief Executive will be accompanied by Mrs Tung; and the Director of Beijing Office, Mr Bowen Leung.
Mr Tung will return to Hong Kong on September 28.
19981012_012.e: Chief Executive's duty visit to Beijing
The Chief Executive, Mr Tung Chee Hwa, will leave Hong Kong for Beijing on Thursday (October 15) evening for his annual duty visit.

He will be accompanied by Mrs Betty Tung, Private Secretary to Chief Executive, Mr Joshua Law; Press Secretary to Chief Executive, Miss Au King-chi, and Special Assistant to Chief Executive, Mr Chan Kin-ping.
During his stay in Beijing, Mr Tung will call on CPG leaders.
Mr Tung will leave Beijing on Saturday (October 17) and proceed on leave until October 27 (Tuesday).
Mr and Mrs Tung will take a vacation in the Mainland.
When Mr Tung is on duty visit and on leave, the Chief Secretary for Administration, Mrs Anson Chan, will be the Acting Chief Executive until her departure for overseas visit on October 22 (Thursday).
Thereafter, the Financial Secretary, Mr Donald Tsang, will be the Acting Chief Executive until Mr Tung resumes duty on October 28.
19990303_057.e: Chief Executive leaves for Beijing tomorrow
The Chief Executive, Mr Tung Chee Hwa, will leave for Beijing tomorrow (Thursday) morning.

At 4 pm tomorrow, Mr Tung will host a cocktail reception in Xi Da Ting (the West Hall) of The Great Hall of the People to mark the official opening of the Beijing Office of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region.
The Vice Premier, Mr Qian Qichen, will be the principal officiating guest at the opening ceremony.

At the invitation of the Standing Committee of the National People's Congress, the Chief Executive will attend the opening ceremony of the second session of the Ninth National People's Congress on Friday (March 5).
Mr Tung will have other engagements and meetings with officials of the Central Government on Friday and Saturday before returning to Hong Kong on Saturday evening.

Accompanying Mr Tung on the visit will be the Information Coordinator, Mr Stephen Lam; the Private Secretary to the Chief Executive, Mr Joshua Law; and Special Assistant to the Chief Executive, Mr Chan Kin-ping.
The Chief Executive will also be accompanied by Mrs Tung.
20000224_014.e: CE to attend NPC opening ceremony

At the invitation of the Standing Committee of the National People's Congress, the Chief Executive, Mr Tung Chee Hwa, will attend the opening ceremony of the third session of the Ninth National People's Congress in Beijing on March 5, a Government spokesman said today (Thursday).
"Mr Tung will depart for Beijing on March 4 and return to Hong Kong on March 6.
We are finalising the Chief Executive's programme in Beijing and an announcement will be made in due course," the spokesman said.

Accompanying Mr Tung on the visit will be the Information Coordinator, Mr Stephen Lam; the Private Secretary to the Chief Executive, Mr Richard Yuen; and Special Assistant to the Chief Executive, Mr Chan Kin-ping.
The Chief Executive will also be accompanied by Mrs Tung.
19991218_003.e: The Chief Executive, Mr Tung Chee Hwa, met with three visitors who were passing through Hong Kong en route to attend the Handover Ceremony and related events in Macao this afternoon (Saturday).

They are the Princess of Thailand, Her Royal Highness Princess Maha Chakri Sirindhorn, the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Foreign Affairs of Belgium, Mr Louis Michel, and the European Commissioner in charge of External Relations, Mr Christopher Patten.
The Chief Executive recalled the visit of Her Royal Highness to attend the Handover Ceremony in 1997 and warmly welcomed her visiting Hong Kong again.

With the Deputy Prime Minister of Belgium, Mr. Tung said that with China's expected accession to the World Trade Organisation, Hong Kong would continue to provide a most important springboard for Belgian companies to invest in the Mainland.
At the meeting with the European Commissioner, Mr Patten, the Chief Executive noted that EU was our third largest trading partner in the world in 1998.
Mr. Tung believed that bilateral trade and investment relations would grow even stronger.
The Chief Executive said that Hong Kong had always supported China's accession to WTO.
This would be important to the Hong Kong economy and we hoped that the European Union would reach agreement with China at an early date.

Turning to increased travel convenience for Hong Kong people, Mr Tung said that a visa-free policy towards HKSAR passport holders would be beneficial to the promotion of trade, economic and tourism ties between Hong Kong and the EU.
Mr Tung hoped that the European Commission would support granting visa-free access to holders of HKSAR passports.

Photo: The Chief Executive, Mr Tung Chee Hwa, met with the Princess of Thailand, Her Royal Highness Princess Maha Chakri Sirindhorn, the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Foreign Affairs of Belgium, Mr Louis Michel, and the European Commissioner in charge of External Relations, Mr Christopher Patten, at separate meetings.
The three visitors are passing through Hong Kong en route to attend the Handover Ceremony and related events in Macao.
The Chief Executive, Mr Tung Chee Hwa, photographed with the Belgian Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Foreign Affairs, Mr Louis Michel, at the Chief Executive's Office after a meeting.
19990202_028.e: CE seeks Israel's secrets of high-tech success
The Chief Executive, Mr Tung Chee Hwa, yesterday (Monday, HK time) said he hopes to learn the 'secrets of success' of Israel's high-tech industries during his landmark three-day visit to the country.
On his first official day of engagements, Mr Tung received a warm welcome from Israel's Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, Israeli Foreign Minister Ariel Sharon and President Ezer Weizman.

Speaking during a lunch hosted by Mr Sharon, the Chief Executive said: "I'm here to see for myself first hand how Israel has become successful and also to see for myself especially in areas of innovation of technology which have impressed almost everybody around the world.
"I hope during my trip my colleagues and I will have the time to study the secrets of your success and that there will also be opportunities for our private sectors to work together."
Mr Tung repeated this theme during his meeting with Mr Netanyahu, noting that Hong Kong's economic base could be broadened through the commercialisation of new and innovative technology.
"I'm sure we will see and learn a lot during our next two days when we visit your universities, companies and centres for technology development," Mr Tung said during his meeting with Mr Netanyahu.
Prime Minister Netanyahu said the Chief Executive's visit set a wonderful precedent for growing relations between Hong Kong and Israel.

He said a major investment by a Hong Kong telecommunications company had 'changed the face' of the cellular phone market in Israel and he was expecting to see 'many, many more' investments from Hong Kong.
"Hong Kong has been, for many of us, a model of the application of free-market principles in a small place," he said.
"I believe your population is about six million and with a per capita income amongst the highest in the world - about US$25,000.
"We're moving up to US$18,000 and we'll try to the best of our abilities to catch you but in this endeavour we are not competitors we are partners.
"You should know we welcome your visit here, you personally and your delegation.
And the more we do business the better and better."

Mr Tung started his first full day's programme in Jerusalem with a breakfast meeting with Israel's President Ezer Weizman at which a wide range of issues were discussed including Hong Kong's reunification, the Asian financial turmoil, Israel's high-tech development and the ongoing peace process in the region.

Following the breakfast meeting, Mr Tung visited the grave of the late Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin, where he and Mrs Tung laid a wreath and, in line with Jewish tradition, placed a small stone on the grave as a symbol of their visit.

The Hong Kong delegation later visited the Martyrs' and Heroes' Memorial of the Holocaust, where Mr Tung laid a wreath in Remembrance Hall to commemorate the six million Jews murdered by the Nazi regime during World War II.
The group then visited United Nations Hill, a scenic vantage point overlooking the old and new sections of Jerusalem as well as the former Israel-Jordan border area from 1948 to 1967.
From there, Mr Tung and the Hong Kong delegation visited Mt Zion, where they were shown the Tomb of King David as well as the room where Jesus Christ is said to have taken the Last Supper.
Following the lunch with Mr Sharon and the meeting with Mr Netanyahu, Mr Tung visited the Israel Museum where he viewed sacred scriptures such as the Dead Sea Scrolls.

Later today Mr Tung will meet Israel's Industry and Trade Minister Natan Sharansky and the governor of the Bank of Israel Professor Ya'acov Frenkel before leaving for Tel Aviv and a series of in-depth briefings on Israel's high-tech development and industries.
19990708_020.e: The Chief Executive, Mr Tung Chee Hwa, will visit San Francisco and the Silicon Valley on July 21 and 22 respectively, a Government spokesman announced today (Thursday).
In San Francisco, Mr Tung will call on the Mayor of the City and meet with business and community leaders.
He will visit a number of information technology companies in the Silicon Valley.
"The Chief Executive will take the opportunity of the visit to brief his interlocutors in the US on the latest developments in Hong Kong.
He will emphasise Hong Kong's advantages as a business and service centre, and the importance the SAR attaches to the development of IT and other high value-added industries," the spokesman said.

Accompanying the Chief Executive on the visit will be the Secretary for Trade and Industry, Mr Chau Tak Hay; the Information Coordinator, Mr Stephen Lam; the Director-General of Industry, Mr Francis Ho; the Deputy Secretary for Information Technology and Broadcasting, Ms Eva Cheng; and the Private Secretary to the Chief Executive, Mr Joshua Law.
The Chief Executive will also be accompanied by Mrs Tung.
19991118_010.e: Chief Executive's duty visit to Beijing
The Chief Executive, Mr Tung Chee Hwa, will leave for Beijing on Sunday (November 21) for his annual duty visit, a Government spokesman announced today (Thursday).
Mr Tung will return on November 22.
During his stay, Mr Tung will call on President Jiang Zemin, Premier Zhu Rongji and Vice Premier Qian Qichen.

The Chief Executive will be accompanied by the Information Coordinator, Mr Stephen Lam; Private Secretary to the Chief Executive, Mr Richard Yuen; and Special Assistant to the Chief Executive, Mr Chan Kin-ping.
