"Nice Movements - Contemporary French Art", one of the major programmes of Le French May, will be on show at the Leisure and Cultural Services Department's Hong Kong Museum of Art from April 20, 2000 until June 25, 2000.
Fifty-six masterpieces by 11 noted artists active in Nice will be featured in this exhibition, offering the audience a glimpse of the various significant movements from the 1950s to 1970s.
The city Nice in Southern France is a famous vacation place with charming scenery and relax mood.
The setting of Mediterranean sun and blue also inspire various important masters to attempt new explorations in artistic creation.
Representative works by these 11 artists will illustrate the new concepts and development of Nice art movements and bring new vision and fresh aspirations for the audience.

Artists such as Cesar, Klein, Arman, Raysse, Gilli and Bernar Venet were pioneers of the New Realism, Pop and Conceptual who devoted to create works of painting, assemblage and collage by using consumers' product, junk and other daily objects to link up art and the life of people with social messages.

Ben and other Fluxus artists of the period pronounced a spirit of anarchism and denounced the formalities of art, making it no difference from life and everything and utilized common language and concerts to create new artistic vocabulary.
Whereas the Supports / Surfaces group recaptured the true essence of painting and proceeded new ideological experiments with the surfaces and materials, thus making painting a vehicle of the society.
Emergence of these art trends ultimately contributed to the formation of the so-called I'Ecole de Nice (School of Nice) which has profound influence on the evolvement of contemporary art.
The exhibition will be on at the Special Exhibition Gallery of the Museum of Art.

It is jointly presented by the Leisure and Cultural Services Department and the Consulate General of France, Hong Kong; supported by the Association FranCaise d'Action Artistique, Ministry of Foreign Affairs, France; sponsored by LVMH; guest curated by Mr Jean-FranCois Mozziconacci, Director of Museums in Nice and organised by the Hong Kong Museum of Art.
The Hong Kong Museum of Art is located at 10 Salisbury Road, Tsim Sha Tsui.
It opens from 10 am to 6 pm daily (including Sundays and public holidays) and closes on Thursdays.
Admission fee is $10, with half-price concessions for senior citizens, people with disabilities and full-time students.
19991117_009.e: "Chinese Dinosaur Fossils" Exhibition at Science Museum
The following is issued on behalf of the Provisional Urban Council:

Following the huge success of the two exhibitions on robotic dinosaurs -- "Dinosaur Alive" and "Prehistoric Giants" -- held in 1993 and 1996 respectively, the Hong Kong Science Museum will stage a genuine dinosaur fossils exhibition from December 14,1999.
Entitled "Chinese Dinosaur Fossils", this special exhibition will be the largest exhibition of its kind ever held in China.
The dinosaur skeletons and fossil specimens to be exhibited have just arrived in Hong Kong.
A meet-the-media session for viewing the crate-opening and the mounting of exhibits took place at the Science Museum this morning (November 17).
Fourteen magnificent dinosaur skeletons will be on display.

They include the Mamenchisaurus, the one with the longest neck in the dinosaurs' family; Yangchuanosaurus , the largest carnivorous dinosaur in this exhibition; the Huayangosaurus, known as the very primitive stegosaurus; and the Tuojiangosaurus, the dinosaur which had the largest number of bony plates.

A precious collection of fossil specimens uncovered in China will also be featured, ranging from the ancient animal and plant fossils, fossils of dinosaur bones, skull, teeth, eggs to the footprints of dinosaurs.
These exhibits were selected from the fine collections of Beijing Natural History Museum, Chongqing Natural History Museum and Zigong Dinosaur Museum.
Surrounded by the prehistoric forest settings, visitors will have the opportunity to explore the dinosaurs' lives in their habitat.
They can also play the role as a fossil detective to identify the differences between carnivorous and herbivorous dinosaurs in the "Fossil Detective" game.
In addition, they can challenge themselves on the knowledge of dinosaurs in the "Dinosaur Quiz" computer game.
This large-scale exhibition is presented by the Provisional Urban Council in association with the Chinese Association of Natural Science Museums and the Guangdong Southern Natural Museum.
It is a major event of the two Municipal Councils to celebrate the new millennium and also a Spotlight Hong Kong Event supported by the Hong Kong Tourist Association.
The exhibition will run until June 11, 2000.
The Hong Kong Science Museum is located at 2 Science Museum Road, Tsim Sha Tsui East.

Admission fee for the exhibition is $30 (for both permanent exhibitions and "Chinese Dinosaur Fossils" exhibition), and $10 (for "Chinese Dinosaur Fossils" exhibition only), with half-price concessions for senior citizens, people with disabilities and full-time students.
Admission for permanent exhibitions is free on Wednesdays but this does not apply to "Chinese Dinosaur Fossils" exhibition.
The Museum will open from 1 pm to 9 pm daily except on Mondays and the first two days of Lunar New Year when the Museum is closed, and from 10 am to 9 pm on Saturdays, Sundays and public holidays.
The Museum will be closed at 5 pm on Christmas Eve (December 24) and Lunar New Year's Eve (February 4).
For enquiries, please call 2732 3232.

20000127_035.e: Efforts to enhance community's awareness of fire safety
The Government and District Fire Safety Committees will continue their joint efforts to enhance the community's awareness of fire safety.

Speaking at a press briefing today (Thursday), the Deputy Director of Home Affairs, Mr Lui Hau-tuen said: "District Fire Safety Committees (DFSCs), set up in all 18 districts by the Home Affairs Department between March 1998 and mid-December 1999, play an important role in enhancing community involvement and public awareness of fire safety.

"The DFSCs have organised a variety of publicity and educational activities on fire safety in the districts including fire safety inspections, fire drills and demonstrations, fire safety talks and seminars, visits to fire stations, "Best Fire Safety Building" competitions, fire safety carnivals, and community involvement activities in hill fire prevention.
"They have also produced newsletters, publicity leaflets and booklets, videos and CD-Roms on fire safety for distribution in their districts.
"They have been very effective in disseminating the fire safety message to all sectors of the community," Mr Lui added.

"DFSCs from eight districts with cubicle apartments in private residential buildings, including Central and Western, Wan Chai, Eastern, Yau Tsim Mong, Sham Shui Po, Kwun Tong, Tsuen Wan and Kwai Tsing, also help spread the fire safety message among residents of cubicle apartments.

"In view of the living conditions and insufficient fire safety installations in cubicle apartments, residents should take extra fire precautions for the sake of safety of their own lives and properties.
"They should not store excessive fuel for cooking purposes, should always keep a clear fire access and be extra careful in using electrical appliances," Mr Lui said.
"The DFSCs in all 18 districts will continue their efforts to support the fire safety Campaign and to organise activities to cater for the needs of residents in their districts," Mr Lui added.
Also meeting the media today were the Chief Fire Officer (Fire Safety) of the Fire Services Department, Mr Allan Lee and representatives of DFSCs from the eight districts.
19981021_009.e: Committee focusing on fire safety
The Secretary for Home Affairs, Mr David Lan, today (Wednesday) stressed the need to promote a fire safety culture among members of the public in view of the dry weather in the coming months.

Speaking at a press briefing following a meeting of the Central Steering Committee on Fire Safety today (Wednesday), Mr Lan said the No. 3 alarm fire in Ngau Tau Kok Road on Monday (October 19) had highlighted the urgency for owners and tenants to comply with building and fire safety regulations.
Referring to the announcement in this year's Policy Address, Mr Lan said the Government aimed to introduce legislation in 1999 to require the upgrading of fire safety in composite buildings.
The Fire Services Department (FSD) will issue advisory letters to encourage owners to improve fire safety before legislation is in place.
Enforcement action to require compliance with existing legislation will continue to be stepped up.
Mr Lan said the FSD had been stepping up inspections in private buildings, particularly composite (commercial/residential) buildings, in view of their higher fire risks.
The FSD has been following up on the fire hazards identified in a territory-wide building survey.
Up to August 31, more than 2,700 Fire Hazard Abatement Notices have been issued requiring responsible persons to remove the hazards.
The Electrical and Mechanical Services Department (EMSD) will step up inspection of electrical installation in buildings to ensure compliance with the relevant safety requirements.

Mr Lan said the Government planned to organise another large-scale fire safety publicity campaign in 1999/2000 to further enhance public awareness of fire safety as well as to cultivate and sustain a fire safety culture in the community.

In order to promote the awareness of fire safety at district level, the Home Affairs Department (HAD) will speed up the establishment of District Fire Safety Committees (DFSCs) to disseminate the message of fire safety.
The DFSCs include representatives from all relevant government departments, local community leaders and professionals known for their expertise and interest in the subject.
The next batch of three DFSCs will be established in Kwun Tong, Tuen Mun and Wan Chai in December.
By the end of 1999, there will be DFSCs to cover all 18 districts.
Mr Lan also urged the public to make use of the Building Management Resource Centre (BMRC) set up in April this year.
Plans to open the second BMRC, to be located on Hong Kong Island, and the third one, in Tsuen Wan, are underway.
Meanwhile, the FSD has expanded the Fire Safety Ambassadors Scheme, with membership to increase from 1,500 to 4,000 by the end of this year.
The programme will be further expanded in 1999, with the FSD proposing to recruit caretakers as Ambassadors.
The meeting also discussed at length the outcome of a two-month public consultation launched in June this year to improve fire safety in private buildings.
Mr Lan told members that the Government would co-ordinate a programme for full implementation of proposals contained in the paper to improve fire safety in private buildings.
Members noted that the community was supportive of the objective to improve fire safety and building management in private buildings.

There was also general consensus that there existed a close correlation between good building management and fire safety, and that Bureaux and Departments should make concerted efforts on the following aspects:
* compulsory building management for problematic buildings;
* upgrading of fire safety standards in private buildings;
* removal of unauthorised building works affecting fire safety; and
* monitoring of maintenance of communal electrical installations in buildings.
Mr Lan said services rendered by the HAD on building management were generally recognised by the public.
The HAD will continue to improve and expand its services and assist building owners to solve building management problems as far as resources allow.
20000126_017.e: LCQ17: Fire and building safety of buildings with cubicles
Following is a question by the Hon Ma Fung-kwok and a written reply by the Secretary for Home Affairs, Mr David Lan, in the Legislative Council today (Wednesday):
Question :
Regarding the number, fire service installations and safety of cubicle apartments in private residential buildings, will the Government inform this Council whether:

(a) it has conducted surveys to find out the average number of cubicle apartments for separate occupation in private residential buildings in each of the past three years; whether the figures show an upward trend in the number of cubicle apartments; if so, of the reasons for that, and whether the increase in the number of new arrivals is one of the reasons;

(b) there is any legislation governing the fire service installations required in premises which have been partitioned into a number of cubicles; if there is, whether it plans to enhance law enforcement actions; if there are such plans, of the relevant details; if there is no such legislation, whether it will consider introducing legislation to that effect; and
(c) it has plans for stepping up promotional efforts to raise fire safety awareness among residents in cubicle apartments?
Reply:
Madam President,
My reply to the three parts of the question is as follows-

(a) we have not conducted specific surveys of cubicle apartments but in the General Household Survey conducted by the Census and Statistics Department in the third quarter of 1999, about 77000 households (population : 167000) were found to be living in non self-contained quarters in private buildings or rooftop quarters.
We have no information on the correlation between the number of cubicle apartments and new arrivals;
(b) regulatory controls of building and fire safety of private buildings are undertaken by the Buildings Department (BD) and Fire Services Department (FSD).
If cubicles adversely affect the structure of a building, or if the means of escape are compromised, enforcement action will be taken as a matter of priority by BD under the Buildings Ordinance.
FSD has statutory power under the Fire Services Ordinance to abate fire hazards, the overwhelming majority of which exist in the common parts of buildings.
Examples of fire hazards include obstruction to means of escape, and defective or missing fire service installations and equipment.

We consider that vigorous enforcement of the existing Ordinances is adequate to regulate the fire and building safety of private buildings containing cubicles and therefore we do not consider it necessary to introduce a separate legislation for the purpose at this stage; and
(c) we have an ongoing plan of promoting fire safety awareness among owners and residents of buildings as follows-

1. Under the auspices of the Central Steering Committee on Fire Safety chaired by me, the Home Affairs Department (HAD) has an ongoing publicity programme to promote effective building management and fire safety.
2. From March 1998 to mid-December 1999, District Fire Safety Committees (DFSCs) were established in all 18 Districts in Hong Kong.
DFSCs play an important role to help promote a fire safety culture in the community.
3. On 5 December 1999, FSD in conjunction with the Information Services Department conducted a major fire prevention campaign at the Hong Kong Cultural Centre Piazza.
The main theme of the campaign was "¦u±æ¬Û§U,°µ¦n¨¾¤õ".
As a continuation of this campaign, a series of high profile fire safety publicity activities are being conducted at major shopping malls and public housing estates throughout Hong Kong.

4. In addition, in an effort to raise public awareness of fire safety, FSD conducted over 2000 fire protection talks and organized 612 fire drills for building owners, occupiers and property management companies in the last 12 months.
FSD has published an information booklet entitled "Fire Prevention in the Home" for handing out to the general public at the fire safety publicity activities.
5. HAD also published a "Fire Safety Checklist" to facilitate owners and occupiers to carry out self-inspection of fire safety provisions of their buildings.
The checklist has been well received by the public.
These checklists and the FSD's booklets mentioned above are available free of charge at the District Offices and Building Management Resource Centres of HAD.
The above publicity and education efforts have enhanced the community's awareness of fire safety and benefited building owners and occupants, including those living in cubicle apartments.
These efforts will continue vigorously.
19981027_020.e: The Fire Safety Roving Exhibitions was launched today (Tuesday.
The exhibition will be staged in five shopping malls throughout Hong Kong in the coming months.

Director of Fire Services (Designate), Mr Tsang Kwong-yu urged the public to pay attention to the importance of fire safety and announced the theme for the year to be "Fire Safety and I" during the opening ceremony.
"It is everyone's responsibility to prevent fire.
We can all help eliminate fire risks by keeping means of escape free of obstruction, making sure smoke stop doors are closed and exit doors unlocked.
In this way, we can protect our lives and property," he said.
Mr Tsang added that the roving exhibition series was part of the efforts of the Government to promote fire safety messages and was organised by the Central Steering Committee on Fire Safety.

The exhibition is about major causes of fire, fire hazards in industrial, commercial and residential premises; fire service installation and equipment, fire safety and building safety improvement loan scheme, fire safety ambassador scheme, fire safety on building construction, fire safety and building management and how security guards may prevent fire.
A programme on fire safety produced by RTHK is also screened in the exhibition.
The first exhibition of the series is staged at Times Square, Causeway Bay from October 27 onwards for three days, followed by exhibition at Hollywood Plaza, Diamond Hill on 6 November.
The exhibition will also be mounted at New Century Place, Mong Kok, Shatin New Town Plaza and Metroplaza, Kwai Fong.
Besides the roving exhibitions, Fire Services Department is organising other promotion activities on fire safety.

"Our department has joined hands with the Institution of Fire Engineers (Hong Kong Branch) to launch the Fire Asia 98, the main objective is to promote fire safety culture and to explore latest fire service management skills," Mr Tsang said.

Also attending the opening ceremony today were Deputy Secretary for Security, Ms Chang King-yiu; Deputy Director of Buildings, Mr Cheng Wei-dart; Deputy Director of Home Affairs, Mr Lui Hau-tuen and Assistant Director of Information Services, Mr Joe Yiu.
19981123_024.e: Improvement programme to enhance fire safety
The Hong Kong Government has formulated a comprehensive improvement programme to enhance fire safety, the Secretary for Security, Mrs Regina Ip, said today (Monday).

The programme included strengthening the legislative and administrative framework to upgrade fire safety facilities in old buildings, stepping up inspections and enforcement actions, and promoting a fire safety culture among the building management profession in particular and the community in general, Mrs Ip said.

Speaking at the opening ceremony of the Fire Asia' 98 Conference and Exhibition, Mrs Ip said Hong Kong, like many other metropolitan cities, faced the problem of having many old buildings equipped with outdated or ill-maintained fire service installations.

The Hong Kong Fire Services Department (FSD) would step up enforcement action to require buildings to reinstate defective or missing fire service installations to approved standards, and to abate fire hazards, Mrs Ip said.
"In 1999, the Department aims to conduct 7 000 inspections of private buildings to ensure that the fire safety requirements are complied with.
"It will also review the Fire Services Ordinance to strengthen its enforcement against fire hazards," Mrs Ip added.

While the Government would do its part to strengthen the legislative framework and step up enforcement action, Mrs Ip stressed that the community should contribute by maintaining their fire safety installations and reporting identified fire hazards.
"We will raise the fire safety awareness of the community through enhanced publicity and promotion of community involvement in the fight against fire," she said.
The FSD will conduct 1 600 fire drills for building owners and occupants and organise 2 200 seminars, exhibitions and talks on fire safety in the coming year.
Among the various new initiatives, Mrs Ip said a Fire Safety Ambassador Scheme was introduced which was mainly targeted at the younger generation.

Members of the Scouts Association of Hong Kong and the Hong Kong Red Cross will be trained and appointed as Fire Safety Ambassadors who will help report fire hazards to the FSD and convey fire safety messages to the general public.
Mrs Ip said: "Another key component of our fight fire policy is to help building owners to help themselves.
"We encourage and assist owners to manage their buildings properly.

We have prepared a Fire Safety Checklist to facilitate owners or occupants to carry out routine inspections on fire safety provisions of their own buildings and to rectify minor irregularities identified," Mrs Ip said.

A Building Management Resource Centre was established in June this year to provide information, services and advice for building owners, residents, Owners Corporations, Mutual Aid Committees and management bodies so as to assist them in improving the standards of management, safety and maintenance of their buildings.

The President of the Hong Kong Branch of the Institution of Fire Engineers (IFE), Mr John Tsang Kwong-yu, said this was the fourth time that an international fire engineering conference was being held in Hong Kong.

He said: "Through the 30 sessions of talks, workshops and case studies in this 3-day Conference, we will study the various approaches made in eastern and western countries in enhancing the fire safety of old buildings and will attempt to develop an integrated approach to raise their fire safety standards."
The Fire Asia' 98 is jointly organised by the Hong Kong Branch of the IFE and the United Kingdom-based Loss Prevention Council, and is supported by the Hong Kong FSD.
Speakers from the Mainland included the Director of the Fire Department, General Sun Lun; and the Deputy Chief of the Scientific Division, Mr Gao Wei; both from the Public Security Ministry.
They are joined by representatives from other countries including Belgium, Canada, Japan, Malaysia, the United Kingdom and United States.
More than 200 delegates including about 40 fire chiefs from a number of eastern and western countries attended the
3-day conference held at the new extension of the Hong Kong Convention and Exhibition Centre.
The theme of the conference is "Strive for a safer world - an integrated experience."
19980621_002.e: Fire safety begins at home
Citizens in Hong Kong should work together to maintain and upkeep fire safety measures, the Secretary for Home Affairs, Mr David Lan, said today (Sunday).
Mr Lan made the appeal at the opening ceremony of the Fire Safety Publicity Campaign 1998/99 this afternoon.
"It is the responsibility of property owners and residents to protect their lives and property by maintaining fire safety measures," he said.
Mr Lan said that a Central Steering Committee on Fire Safety was set up.
Its membership consists of six bureau secretaries and department heads as well as seven non-official members to strengthen policies, education and publicity on fire safety.

The Fire Safety Publicity Campaign was launched under the Committee and was co-organised by Home Affairs Bureau, Security Bureau, Planning, Environment and Lands Bureau, Fire Services Department, Buildings Department, Home Affairs Department and Information Services Department.

The Director of Fire Services, Mr Peter Cheung, who was also present today, hoped that the public's awareness on the need of fire safety measures and their understanding of the destructive power of fire could be increased through a series of promotion activities.
"We have disseminated through negative figure 'Fire Devil' and positive image 'Fire Safety Star' the essence of fire safety messages," he said.

During the opening ceremony, local TV artistes Mr Louis Koo, Miss Esther Kwan, Mr Waise Lee and Miss Jay Leung literally played the part of "Fire Safety Stars" and demonstrated how to combat the "Fire Devil".

The "Fire Devil" with the slogan "Fire Kills Prevent Fire" would be carried in a series of publicity items including a new Television Announcement in the Public Interest (TV API), poster, leaflet, booklet, and stickers.
The TV API was premiered today.
Promotion activities on fire safety would also be launched by Home Affairs Department and Fire Services Department.
"We will have more concerted inter-departmental clearance operations to remove obstructions in means of escape and more Fire Safety Committees on district level," Mr David Lan said.
"An unprecedented Building Management Resource Centre would be opened soon to provide professional services to property owners, residents and Owners' Corporations," he added.
"One of our major programmes is the Fire Safety Ambassador Scheme.
We have already trained 438 tutors and 289 ambassadors up till May.
They will help prevent fire and deliver messages on fire safety to the public," Mr Peter Cheung said.
"We have already organised 283 talks, nine exhibitions and 62 fire drills to educate the public on fire safety and what to do in case of fire," he said.

Also attending the opening ceremony today were acting Director of Buildings, Mr Cheng Wei-dart; Deputy Director of Home Affairs, Mr Lui Hau-tuen; Deputy Secretary for Security, Ms Chang King-yiu; Assistant Director of Information Services, Mr Joe Yiu; and Principal Assistant Secretary for Planning, Environment and Lands, Mr Esmond Lee.
19981129_006.e: New fire safety legislation in the pipeline
The Government is studying how to improve the fire safety standards of all composite buildings by introducing new legislation, the Secretary for Security, Mrs Regina Ip, said today (Sunday).

Speaking at the launching ceremony of the annual Fire Prevention Campaign 1998/99 at the Hong Kong Cultural Centre Piazza, Mrs Ip said the new fire safety legislation was expected to be enacted in the 1999/2000 legislative session.

"Besides stepping up enforcement actions to ensure that property owners or management bodies would upkeep and improve the fire service structures and installations of their buildings, we will raise the fire safety awareness of the community," Mrs Ip said.
She said the Government had strengthened publicity on building management to encourage property owners to look into the fire safety of their buildings.
The Fire Services Department (FSD) had also expanded the Fire Safety Ambassador Scheme and its membership would be increased from 1 500 to 4 000 by the end of the year, Mrs Ip said.
She added that the FSD planned to recruit caretakers to become Fire Safety Ambassadors through the Home Affairs Department and local community organisations next year.
Also at the ceremony, the Director of Fire Services, Mr John Tsang Kwong-yu, said it was everyone's responsibility to prevent fires.
He said: "We can all help eliminate fire risks by keeping means of escape free of obstruction, making sure that smoke stop doors are closed and exit doors unlocked."
Mr Tsang urged the management of each organisation to actively promote fire safety awareness among its staff and arrange various fire safety activities such as fire drills and talks.

"Our department joined the Institution of Fire Engineers to stage the Fire Asia 98 conference and exhibition last week with the aim of promoting fire safety culture and exploring the latest fire service management skills," Mr Tsang said.

The delegates from various countries had exchanged the latest skills and experiences in fire services during the conference, and the local fire services personnel had also introduced the new knowledge and techniques to maintain Hong Kong's fire services technology at world standards, he added.

Programmes included water-jetting display by a fireboat, exhibition booths mounted by various government departments, performances by the Fire Services Chinese Musical Band, Commercial Radio artistes, TVB "Fire Safety Stars" and Fire Safety Ambassadors.
20000309_021.e: Roving Exhibitions to promote Fire Safety
The Central Steering Committee on Fire Safety will organise a series of roving exhibitions in three shopping arcades in March and April.
To arouse public awareness on fire safety, the theme of Fire Safety Roving Exhibitions 1999/2000 will be on "Neighbourhood Assistance".

The contents of the exhibition include major causes of fire; fire risks in residential, commercial and industrial buildings; the Fire Safety (Commercial Premises) Ordinance; operation of the hose reel system; Fire Safety Ambassador Scheme; fire safety measures in private buildings and public housing estates; prevention of hill fire; role of security guards in preventing fire; and building management and fire safety.
Besides the display panels, a computer kiosk will be set up for visitors to take part in the fire safety computer quiz to see if they grasp the basic knowledge of fire safety.
Meanwhile, fire safety promotional videos will also be screened at the venues of the exhibitions.
The first exhibition will be staged at Discovery Park, Tsuen Wan from March 11 to 14, followed by an exhibition at Times Square, Causeway Bay, from March 24 to 26.
The last exhibition will be mounted at Lok Fu Shopping Centre from March 31 to April 5.
19971217_022.e: Fire safety of old buildings
Following is a question by the Hon Kennedy Wong Ying- ho and a written reply by the Secretary for Security, Mr Peter Lai, in the Provisional Legislative Council today (Wednesday):
Question:
As the fire-fighting facilities in some older buildings in the territory are below the fire safety standard, in the present dry season of high risk of fire, will the Government inform this Council:
(a) of the immediate measures in place to lower the fire hazards of these buildings; and

(b) whether consideration has been given to improving, by legislative means, the fire-fighting facilities in these buildings, such as requiring a greater number of fire extinguishers and the provision of fire- proof blankets?
Reply:
Madam President,
(a) Older buildings in the territory were constructed according to the fire safety standards at the time when they were built.

However, it does not mean that those buildings are of a high risk of fire, if their fire safety installation and equipment are properly maintained, and that the owners and occupiers take adequate fire safety precautions and observe fire safety.
To ensure that proper fire safety measures are taken, the Fire Services Department (FSD) has stepped up inspections during the dry season.
In October and November 1997, FSD conducted 2,540 inspections to commercial buildings, 1,513 to residential buildings and 524 to industrial buildings.
Fire Hazard Abatement Notices will be issued to order the removal of any fire hazards identified.

The Buildings Department (BD) has conducted 598 inspections to pre-1973 old commercial buildings since May 1997, and has issued 5,823 advisory letters to the owners to encourage them to improve the fire safety conditions of their buildings.
The Labour Department (LD) has been launching a fire safety inspection campaign from October 16, 1997 to December 31, 1997.
This is an intensive law enforcement exercise concentrating on work places where accidents are prone to happen.
Immediate prosecutions will be initiated by the factory inspectors of the LD when serious potential fire risks are detected.
LD also conducted joint inspections with FSD to 36 pre-1973 industrial buildings in early 1997 and 500 advisory letters were sent.

To raise the fire safety awareness of the public during the dry season, FSD launched the 1997/98 fire prevention campaign with the theme "Fire Safety in Commercial and Industrial Buildings" in November 1997.
A series of seminars and activities will be held for the general public to convey fire safety knowledge and message to them.
The Home Affairs Department has frequent contacts with building management bodies, owners' corporations and mutual aid committees to promote fire safety.
The FSD complaint hotline is frequently publicised for the public to report fire hazards to the department.
The LD also organises promotional activities on fire safety at work and publishes booklets and leaflets on fire safety at workplaces frequently.
(b) The Government will introduce legislation to improve the fire safety standard of old commercial buildings.

We are planning to extend the scope of the Fire Safety (Commercial Premises) Ordinance to require the installation of additional fire service installations and equipment (including automatic sprinkler system, fire hydrant/hosereel system and emergency lighting), and improvements to building structure in respect of means of escape, means of access and fire resisting construction in old commercial buildings.
Drafting of the legislation is in progress and we aim to introduce the bill into the Provisional Legislative Council in early 1998.
En
19990505_028.e: District committees to promote fire safety culture

The Government has been actively promoting a fire safety culture, reinforcing building management bodies and enhancing public awareness of fire prevention through the setting up of District Fire Safety Committees (DFSCs), the Deputy Director of Home Affairs, Mr Lui Hau-tuen said today (Wednesday).
Mr Lui made the remarks at the inaugural meeting of the Yuen Long District Fire Safety Committee, which is one of the four DFSCs set up today.

Mr Lui also attended two other DFSC inaugural meetings in the North and Kwai Tsing districts, while another Deputy Director of Home Affairs, Mr Augustine Cheng attended the DFSC inaugural meeting in Wong Tai Sin.
Mr Lui said a Central Steering Committee on Fire Safety had been established to co-ordinate the efforts of various departments to promote fire safety.

"So far, a total of 16 DFSCs have been set up by the Home Affairs Department (HAD) to co-ordinate and organise fire safety activities at the district level and to enhance public awareness of the importance of fire safety.
"Sai Kung and Islands districts are expected to set up their DFSCs in December so that all 18 districts will have their own DFSC by the end of the year," Mr Lui said.

"The HAD plans to organise 80 publicity events on fire safety and building management for 10,000 participants and produce related publicity materials such as leaflets, booklets, TV and Radio Announcements of Public Interest in 1999 - 2000.

"The participation of DFSC members in fire safety publicity events including fire drills, training courses, talks, seminars and exhibitions are found to be very effective in bringing home the fire safety message," he added.

Mr Lui noted that the HAD had, in conjunction with relevant departments, devised a Fire Safety Checklist in layman's terms to facilitate and encourage owners and occupants to carry out routine inspections of the fire safety provisions of their buildings and to rectify promptly the irregularities identified.
So far, more than 130,000 copies of the Checklist had been distributed.

The HAD had also employed temporary staff to help promote fire safety including visiting Owners' Corporations (OC), Mutual Aid Committees (MAC) and building management bodies to distribute and promote the Checklist as well as assisting owners and occupants in conducting self-inspection of buildings by using the Checklist.

Attending the Wong Tai Sin DFSC inaugural meeting, Mr Cheng said: "As the educational and publicity programme on fire safety is an on-going task, its success depends a lot on the valuable advice and active participation of all DFSC members.

"With the concerted efforts of DFSCs and departments concerned, we hope to achieve the goal of enhancing public awareness of fire safety and tackle the problems of fire safety and building management in private buildings."

During the inaugural meetings, all the established DFSCs had pledged to tender advice on preventing hill fire, in addition to tendering advice on multi-storey buildings and residential areas in both the urban areas and the New territories.

Mr Lui and Mr Cheng presented appointment certificates to unofficial members who are either provisional district board members, Area Committee chairmen, OC chairmen, MAC chairmen, local community leaders or interested individuals from various professions.
Official members of DFSCs are representatives from the relevant departments.

19980910_009.e: Seizure of dutiable cigarettes by Customs
Customs officers yesterday (Wednesday) seized 200,000 sticks of smuggled cigarettes and arrested 16 suspects in a territory wide anti-cigarette-smuggling operation.
The value of the seizure is about $270,000, with a duty potential of $150,000.
During the operation code-named "Tornado 105", officers from the Customs Marine and Land Enforcement Command raided several black spots of selling smuggled cigarettes and made the seizure.
The arrested, aged between 23 and 58, have been charged with "dealing with goods to which Dutiable Commodities Ordinance applies".

"Any person found committing the offence, including dealing, selling or purchasing dutiable commodities, will be subject to a maximum penalty of $1 million fine and two years' imprisonment," said a spokesman for the Customs and Excise Department.
The department would continue their anti-cigarette-smuggling operations to smash distribution centres of contraband cigarettes, he added.
19980520_009.e: Seizure of dutiable cigarettes by Customs
Customs officers smashed a smuggled cigarettes mobile storage centre and arrested a suspect following the seizure of 430,000 sticks of dutiable cigarettes in Sha Tin today (Wednesday).
The value of the seizure is $645,000, with a duty potential of $330,000.
Acting on information, officers from Customs Marine and Land Enforcement Command followed their target in Shek Mun, Sha Tin.
At about 2.30 pm, the officers swang into action when seeing the suspect handling cartons of dutiable cigarettes on board a goods vehicle.
"We believe that we have smashed a syndicate active in the distribution of smuggled cigarettes in Sha Tin and Tsuen Wan," a spokesman for the Customs and Excise Department said.
The arrested, a 21-year-old man, will be charged with "dealing with goods to which the Dutiable Commodities Ordinance applies".
The goods vehicle is being impounded pending forfeiture.
The maximum penalty for the offence is a fine of $1 million and imprisonment for two years.
The spokesman stressed that the department was determined to take all efforts to repress all kinds of cigarettes smuggling activities.
19980723_008.e: Seizure of dutiable cigarettes by Customs
Customs officers of the Anti-Cigarette-Smuggling Task Force (ACSTF) seized a total of 1.61 million dutiable cigarettes and arrested three suspects in the past two days.
Yesterday afternoon, Customs officers of ACSTF neutralised a distribution ring which supplied dutiable cigarettes to retail outlets in East Kowloon.
A storage centre in a Yau Tong industrial building was smashed with the seizure of 0.5 million sticks of cigarettes valued at $0.65 million.
The seizure has a duty potential of $0.38 million.
Two men were arrested when they were removing cigarettes from the store located in a flat of an industrial building in Yau Tong.
The two arrested will be charged with "dealing with goods to which the Dutiable Commodities Ordinance applies" under the Dutiable Commodities Ordinance.
The maximum penalties for the offence are a fine of $1 million and imprisonment for two years.
In another development, Customs officers seized from a river trading vessel 1.11 million sticks of cigarettes and arrested the shipmaster in the afternoon of July 21 (Tuesday).
The seizure is valued about $1.4 million and has a duty potential of $0.85 million.
In the first five months of this year, the Customs and Excise Department seized about 38 million sticks cigarettes with a market value of more than $50 million and a duty potential of $28.6 million.
19991029_009.e: Seizure of smuggled cigarettes by Customs

Customs officers of the General Investigation Division last (Thursday) night foiled a smuggling attempt case following the seizure of more than 13 million sticks of dutiable cigarettes, which carried a market value of $17.2 million, and a duty potential of $10 million, on Lautau Island as a result of their constant efforts in combating smuggling activities.
Acting on intelligence and following intensive investigations, Customs officers mounted a surveillance operation at Tung Chung Waterfront Road yesterday.
At about 9:30 pm, the officers swung into action when seeing several men moving hundreds of boxes ashore from two mainland vessels on board three vehicles.
Customs officers intercepted the men immediately and seized a total of 13.21 million sticks of dutiable cigarettes.
Nineteen crew members, all mainlanders, aged between 25 to 43, and six local residents, aged between 26 to 42, were arrested.
The masters of both vessels will appear at Tsuen Wan Magistracy tomorrow, charged with the offence of "Importing unmanifested cargo" under the Import and Export Ordinance.
The maximum penalty for the offence is a fine of $2 million and imprisonment for seven years.
The other arrested people may possibly face the offence of "dealing with goods to which the Dutiable Commodities Ordinance applies" under the Dutiable Commodities Ordinance.
The maximum penalty for the offence is a fine of $1 million and imprisonment of two years.
"There has been an increasing trend of using river trade vessels to smuggle cigarettes into Hong Kong," said a spokesman for the Customs and Excise Department.
From 1996 to 1998, Customs only detected one such case each year with around 1 million illicit cigarettes seized in each case.
"Six such cases have been detected so far this year with 20 million cigarettes seized.
The case detected yesterday was the biggest haul from river trade vessels in one single case," the spokesman added.
Hong Kong Customs is monitoring the situation closely and will devise appropriate enforcement strategy to stem this illicit flow.
"We shall also liaise with our Mainland counterparts for intelligence exchange and enforcement cooperation," he said.
19990830_015.e: Seizure of dutiable cigarettes by Customs

Speedy action by Customs officers led to the seizure of more than 1.1 million sticks of dutiable cigarettes, which carried a market value of $1.45 million, and a duty potential of about $890,000, in the new Territories last Thursday (August 26).
Acting on self-developed investigations, Customs Officers of the Marine and Land Enforcement Command intercepted three light goods vehicles at a Yuen Long carpark at about 12:50 pm on that day.
As a result, they arrested a 21-year-old man and seized 850,000 contraband cigarettes from three vehicles.
Acting on follow-up enquiries, Customs Officers made a further seizure of 310,000 sticks of dutiable cigarettes, at an open space in Shek Kong about three hours later.
The suspect has been charged with related offences and will appear in Tuen Mun Court on September 24.
"Anyone found in breach of the Dutiable Commodities Ordinance is liable to a maximum fine of$1 million and imprisonment of two years," said a spokesman for the Customs and Excise Department.
"The Department will continue its vigorous enforcement actions to check the supply of dutiable cigarettes to show the determination in protecting public revenue," the spokesman stressed.
Meanwhile, the Customs appealed for information on smuggling of cigarettes.
Information could be passed to the Customs hotline 2545 6182.
19990624_023.e: Seizure of dutiable cigarettes by Customs
Speedy action by Customs officers led to the seizure of 2.2 million sticks of dutiable cigarettes worth about $2.9 million within an hour yesterday (Wednesday).
Acting on information, Customs Officers of the Anti-cigarettes Smuggling Task Force intercepted two suspected vehicles for search at a Kowloon Bay carpark at about 3 pm yesterday.
As a result, they seized 1.2 million contraband cigarettes from the vehicles.
During the operation, the officers also arrested five men, aged between 29 and 47.
About an hour later, Customs Officers approached two suspected vehicles for search inside a carpark at Mei Lam Estate in Tai Wai.
The officers arrested three men, aged between 35 and 40, and seized 1 million dutiable cigarettes.

" In both cases, the vehicles are believed to be mobile storage responsible for supplying dutiable cigarette to contraband cigarette distributors in Kowloon East, Shatin and Tai Po areas," said a spokesman for the Customs and Excise Department.
The arrested will be charged under the Dutiable Commodities Ordinance.
The maximum penalty for the offence is a fine of $1 million and imprisonment of two years.
"The Department will continue its vigorous enforcement actions to check the supply of dutiable cigarettes to show the determination in protecting public revenue," the spokesman stressed.
19990323_012.e: Seizure of dutiable cigarettes by Customs
Customs officers yesterday (Monday) seized 2.73 million sticks of dutiable cigarettes, which carried a market value of $3.6 million and a duty potential of $2.09 million, in Tai Po.
Acting on intelligence, Customs Officers of the Anti-cigarettes Smuggling Task Force intercepted a cross-boundary lorry inside a carpark near Yuen Chau Tsai in Tai Po for search.
As a result, they made the seizure and arrested the driver, a 32-year-old man.
"The cigarettes are believed to be imported into Hong Kong through Lok Ma Chau Control Point earlier yesterday.

The vehicle is believed to be a mobile storage responsible for supplying dutiable cigarettes to contraband cigarette distributors in Sheung Shui, Fanling, Tai Po, Sha Tin and Kowloon City areas," said a spokesman for the Customs and Excise Department.
The arrested driver has been charged under the Import and Export Ordinance.
The maximum penalty for the offence is a fine of $2 million and imprisonment of seven years.
"The Department will continue its vigorous enforcement actions to check the supply of dutiable cigarettes to show the determination in protecting public revenue," the spokesman stressed.
19980922_022.e: Seizure of dutiable cigarettes by Customs
Customs officers of Lok Ma Chau Control Point yesterday (Monday) seized 1.8 million dutiable cigarettes worth about $2.3 million, with a duty potential of $1.4 million, from an incoming vehicle.
About 11 am yesterday, an incoming lorry was intercepted by Customs officers for examination at Lok Ma Chau Control Point.
The driver, a 48-year-old man, declared on a manifest that the lorry was carrying 175 packages of textile products.
Upon inspection, 180 cartons containing the contraband cigarettes were found hidden behind the manifested goods.
Follow-up investigations by the Customs General Investigation Division revealed that the cigarettes were destined for Hong Kong.
The driver will appear at the Fanling Magistracy on October 9 to face the charge of "importing unmanifested cargo" under the Import and Export Ordinance.
The maximum penalty for the offence is a fine of $500,000 and imprisonment of two years.
19990120_017.e: Seizure of dutiable cigarettes by Customs
Customs officers yesterday (Tuesday) smashed a distribution centre of contraband cigarettes in San Po Kong following the seizure of 1.36 million dutiable cigarettes.
The seized goods carried a market value of $1.78 million and a duty potential of $1.05 million.
"This was the second significant seizure of dutiable cigarettes effected by the Department in the past five days.
The first case involved the seizure of 9.58 million cigarettes in Kwai Chung Container Terminal last Friday (January 15)," said a spokesman for the Customs and Excise Department.
Following intensive investigations, Customs officers of Anti-Cigarette-Smuggling Task Force yesterday raided an industrial unit in San Po Kong.
As a result, they made the seizure and arrested two men, including an overstayer from the Mainland.
The arrested, aged 27 and 42, will be jointly charged with "Dealing with goods to which the Dutiable Commodities Ordinance applies" under the Dutiable Commodities Ordinance.
The maximum penalty for the offence is a fine of $1 million and imprisonment for two years.
"The Department will continue its vigorous enforcement actions to check the supply of dutiable cigarettes to show the determination in protecting public revenue," the spokesman added.
19990409_015.e: Seizure of dutiable cigarettes by Customs
Customs officers yesterday (Thursday) seized 1.75 million sticks of dutiable cigarettes, which carried a market value of $2.3 million and a duty potential of $1.3 million, in Tai Po.

The maximum penalty for the offence is a fine of $1 million and imprisonment of two years.
"The Department will continue its vigorous enforcement actions to check the supply of dutiable cigarettes to show the determination in protecting public revenue," the spokesman stressed.

19980903_004.e: Aid for flood victims in Mainland
The Disaster Relief Fund Advisory Committee has approved a grant of $1 million to Oxfam Hong Kong for relief for flood victims in Shaanxi, Guangxi and Yunnan, the Mainland.

Together with the earlier grants of $7 million to World Vision Hong Kong, $3 million to Hong Kong Red Cross, $3 million to the Salvation Army, $5.39 million to Medecins Sans Frontieres and $3 million to Hong Kong Committee for United Nations Children's Fund, the Advisory Committee has now approved in total $22.39 million from the Disaster Relief Fund for various relief projects to assist the victims affected by the recent floods in the Mainland.
The Committee hopes that the grants can help to provide some relief to the victims.

To ensure that the money will be used for the purpose designated, the Government has required Oxfam Hong Kong to submit an evaluation report and audited accounts on the use of the grant after the project has been completed.
The Committee is chaired by the Chief Secretary for Administration.

Members include Dr the Hon Raymond Ch'ien, the Hon Yang Ti-liang, the Hon Mrs Sophie Leung Lau Yau-fun, the Hon Lau Chin-shek, Mr Norman Leung, Ms Sansan Ching, the Secretary for Health and Welfare and the Secretary for the Treasury.

19971231_007.e: At the invitation of the Director of the Hong Kong and Macau Affairs office of the State Council, Mr Liao Hui, the Chief Secretary for Administration, Mrs Anson Chan, will visit Beijing on January 5, 1998 (Monday).
This is the Chief Secretary's first visit since the establishment of the Special Administrative Region Government.
During her stay in Beijing, Mrs Chan will exchange views with Mr Liao on subjects of mutual concern to Hong Kong and the Mainland, with a view to strengthening ties and co-operation.
The Chief Secretary will also take the opportunity to call on other senior Chinese officials.

Mrs Chan will be accompanied by her Administrative Assistant, Mr Clement Leung; her Press Secretary, Ms Kitty Choi; Assistant Director of Information Services, Mr Mak Kwok-wah; and Principal Assistant Secretary for Constitutional Affairs, Ms Wendy Cheung.
19980219_008.e: At the invitation of Mr Liao Hui, Director of the Hong Kong and Macau Affairs Office of the State Council, the Financial Secretary, Mr Donald Tsang, will visit Beijing on February 23 and 24.
This is the Financial Secretary's first visit to Beijing after the Handover.
During his visit to Beijing, the Financial Secretary will make courtesy calls to the Vice-Premier and Minister of Foreign Affiars, Mr Qian Qichen and Director Liao.

The Financial Secretary will also meet with the Minister of Finance, Mr Liu Zhongli; the Governor of People's Bank of China, Mr Dai Xianglong; and Chairman of the China Securities Regulatory Commission, Mr Zhou Zhengqing.

The Financial Secretary will discuss with the officials the latest developments in the Asian financial markets and the impact of the financial turmoil on the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region (HKSAR).
He will also take the opportunity to brief them on the first Budget of the HKSAR.
Details of his visit programme are still being worked out.
Mr Tsang will be accompanied by his Administrative Assistant Mr Thomas Chow, Press Secretary Ms Kitty Choi and Assistant Secretary for Constitutional Affairs Miss Rosanna Law.
19990321_002.e: Rendition talks to be held in Beijing
The Secretary for Security, Mrs Regina Ip, will lead a delegation to Beijing tomorrow (Monday) to hold discussions with the Mainland authorities on rendition arrangement.
"The delegation comprises representatives from the Security Bureau, Department of Justice, Police and Constitutional Affairs Bureau," a Government spokesman said.
The Secretary for Security will also make a number of courtesy calls on the Mainland authorities and will return to Hong Kong on March 25.
19980224_004.e: Secretary for Constitutional Affairs to visit Beijing
The Secretary for Constitutional Affairs, Mr Michael Suen, will pay a visit to Beijing between Thursday (February 26) and Saturday this week.
During his stay in Beijing, Mr Suen will call on the Hong Kong and Macau Affairs Office of the State Council and other mainland authorities.
He will have working meetings with mainland officials on issues of mutual concern.
Mr Suen will be accompanied by the Assistant Secretary for Constitutional Affairs, Miss Rosanna Law, and Secretariat Press Officer (Constitutional Affairs), Mr Joe Cheung.
19990503_015.e: A Government spokesman announced today (Monday) that the Chief Secretary for Administration, Mrs Anson Chan, will visit Beijing tomorrow (Tuesday).

Mrs Chan will take the opportunity to call on Chinese leaders and meet with officials in the Hong Kong and Macau Affairs Office and other organs of the Central People's Government to discuss subjects of mutual concern to Hong Kong and the Mainland.

Mrs Chan will be accompanied by her Administrative Assistant, Mr Clement Leung; Principal Assistant Secretary for Constitutional Affairs, Ms Carol Yip; Principal Assistant Secretary for Security, Miss Cathy Chu; and Assistant Director of Information Services, Mr S Y Tam.
19990602_005.e: The Secretary for Justice, Miss Elsie Leung, and the Secretary for Security, Mrs Regina Ip, this (Wednesday) afternoon held a working meeting in Beijing with officials of the Hong Kong and Macau Affairs Office (HKMAO) under the State Council and the Legislative Affairs Commission of the National People's Congress Standing Committee (NPCSC).

"The purpose of the meeting is to go over the report submitted to the State Council earlier by the Chief Executive on the right of abode (ROA) issue," the Secretary for Security told reporters in Beijing after the meeting.
"The State Council is considering the report.
If our request for interpretation of Basic Law articles relevant to the ROA issue by the NPCSC is accepted, the report will be put to the NPCSC," she said.
Among the Mainland officials present at the meeting this afternoon were HKMAO Director Liao Hui and Vice Chairman of the NPCSC Legislative Affairs Commission Qiao Xiaoyang.
Immediately after the meeting, the Secretary for Justice departed for the airport.
She will be back in Hong Kong late this evening.
Mrs Ip, meanwhile, will stay in Beijing for another day to follow up the question of helping Hong Kong people detained in the Mainland.
19991026_011.e: The first 10-member delegation of the Immigration Department, headed by a Principal Immigration Officer, will be leaving on November 3 (Wednesday) for a study visit programme in five cities on the Mainland.
The two-week visit programme aims at enhancing understanding and co-operation with the Mainland authorities and promoting better working relations with them.

Principal Immigration Officer (Documents), Mr Choy Tak-po, accompanied by five officers and four rank-and-file members, under the arrangement of the Hong Kong and Macau Affairs Office (HKMAO), will visit counterparts in Beijing, Fuzhou, Xiamen, Guangzhou and Shenzhen to share working experience.

Visits will be paid to the HKMAO, the Public Security Bureau, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, the Immigration Section of the Beijing Office in Beijing and the Foreign Affairs Office, checkpoints, as well as births and deaths registration offices in other cities.

At a briefing before the departure of the delegation, the Director of Immigration, Mr Ambrose Lee, said that following the reunification, co-operation and communication between the Department and the Mainland authorities are ever increasing.
With a view to facilitating an exchange of knowledge and experience between officers and their Mainland counterparts, we consider a regular study visit programme to the Mainland is highly desirable.
"We hope that such study visits can be organised twice a year so that more officers can participate and benefit," Mr Lee said.
The delegation will return to Hong Kong from Shenzhen on November 15 (Monday).
19981223_012.e: The Secretary for Security, Mrs Regina Ip, has held useful and positive discussions with the Mainland authorities on rendition during her stay in Beijing.
"The discussions mark a good start to future talks on the subject," she said.
Mrs Ip was speaking to reporters today (Wednesday) at the end of her week-long visit to Beijing and Guangzhou.
The purpose of the visit is to hold exploratory discussions with the Mainland authorities on rendition and to pay courtesy calls on the relevant ministries and state agencies.
"The two sides have exchanged their preliminary views on rendition.
Both sides agree that there is a need to put in place a formal arrangement as soon as possible.
"We have reflected the views and concerns of Hong Kong people on the subject to the Mainland authorities and they have been understanding.
"Further talks will be held in due course," Mrs Ip said.

She explained that it would not be appropriate to disclose details of the rendition discussions while they are on-going, in the same manner as discussions were held with other jurisdictions on related subjects.
"We are now in the exploratory stage only and it is too early to talk about the final package..
In formulating an arrangement with the Mainland, we will of course take into account views expressed by legislators and the public.
"The Legislative Council will be consulted on the proposed rendition arrangement after completion of the discussions with the Mainland authorities.
Any legislative proposal to give effect to the rendition arrangement will have to be supported by the public and scrutinised by LegCo before it could be passed into law," she said.

In Beijing, Mrs Ip met senior officials from the Ministry of Public Security, the Hong Kong and Macau Affairs Office of the State Council, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, the Supreme People's Court, the Supreme People's Procuratorate and the Central Military Commission.

In Guangzhou, she paid courtesy calls on the Guangdong Provincial Public Security Department, the Provincial People's Procuratorate, the Provincial Higher People's Court, the Provincial Justice Department and the Provincial Foreign Affairs Office.

Mrs Ip was accompanied on her Mainland trip by Deputy Secretary for Security, Mr Raymond Wong; Principal Assistant Secretary for Security, Mrs Carrie Willis and Assistant Secretary for Security, Mr Albert Cheuk.
This was Mrs Ip's first visit to the Mainland since she took up the post of Secretary for Security in late August.
19980106_003.e: Second day of CS's Beijing visit
The Chief Secretary for Administration, Mrs Anson Chan, today (Tuesday) met with Vice-Premier Qian Qichen at Diaoyutai State Guesthouse.
The Director of the Hong Kong and Macau Affairs Office, Mr Liao Hui, also attended the meeting.
Mr Qian welcomed the visits of senior officials of the SAR government to Beijing.
He said this would effectively enhance the communication between the central government and the SAR.
Vice-Premier and Mrs Chan also discussed the operation of the SAR government and the civil service since the handover.
Vice-Premier said the civil service had achieved a stabilising effect in the transition period, and praised the SAR officials in handling the financial turmoil properly.
After the meeting, Vice-Premier and Mrs Qian hosted a dinner at Diaoyutai State Guesthouse for Mrs Chan.
Before meeting with Mr Qian, Mrs Chan had an 80- minute talk with the Director of Hong Kong and Macau Affairs Office of the State Council, Mr Liao Hui.
They exchanged views on the development of the SAR since its establishment six months ago.
In the meeting, Mr Liao reiterated that under the "one country, two systems" principle, the Hong Kong and Macau Affairs Office definitely would not interfere with the affairs of the SAR.
On the establishment of the HKSAR office in Beijing, Mrs Chan said: "I expressed to the Hong Kong and Macau Affairs Office our wish to set up the HKSAR office in Beijing as early as possible.
Director Liao said that, according to the Basic Law, the establishment of the HKSAR office and its scope of work would be decided by HKSAR Government.
The Hong Kong and Macau Affairs Office would offer practical assistance when necessary."
"In order to set up the HKSAR office as soon as possible, we are going to rent premises before a permanent location is sought."
"The Constitutional Affairs Bureau is actively formulating a proposal on the scope of work and staffing of the office."
Earlier today, Mrs Chan paid a courtesy call on National People's Congress Standing Committee Secretary- General, Mr Cao Zhi, at the reception hall of the Great Hall of the People.
At the meeting, Mr Cao Zhi briefed Mrs Chan on the functions of the National People's Congress (NPC) as the highest organ of power in China.
Mr Cao Zhi said there were five years before the Hong Kong representatives to the NPC would be elected.
During this period, the advice of the public will be seriously considered, with a view to making the arrangements of the next election more satisfactory.
In the afternoon, Mrs Chan met the Deputy Director of Hong Kong and Macau Affairs Office of the State Council, Mr Wang Fengchao, at his office.

Director-General of Department of Social and Cultural Affairs of the HKMAO, Mr Zhao Bingxin; Director-General of Department of Economic Affairs, Mr Zhang Liangdong, and Director-General of Department of Political Affairs, Mr Xu Ze, also attended.
Mrs Chan and Deputy Director Wang Fengchao discussed subjects of mutual concern to Hong Kong and the Mainland including avian flu and mainland-born children with right of abode in Hong Kong.
Deputy Director Wang expressed his concern on the development of avian flu.

Mrs Chan briefed HKMAO officials on the latest situation in Hong Kong and thanked the Guangdong authorities for their cooperation on assisting the SARG in improving the control system for chickens imported from the Mainland.
In addition, Mrs Chan and Mr Wang also exchanged views on the operation of "Certificate of Entitlement Scheme" for the past six months.
They both considered that the scheme operated well and agreed that the Hong Kong people's children who were eligible to right of abode should come to Hong Kong as soon as possible.
Mrs Chan will meet Vice Minister of Foreign Ministry, Mr Wang Yinfan, this morning, and will return to Hong Kong in the afternoon.
19990324_036.e: The Secretary for Security, Mrs Regina Ip, has held a "very useful" round of expert discussions on rendition with the Mainland authorities during her visit to Beijing.
"The experts on both sides had a frank exchange of views and gained a deeper understanding of each other's prevailing systems," she said.

Speaking to reporters today (Wednesday) wrapping up her three-day visit to Beijing, she said that both sides acknowledged that given the immense differences in the legal and judicial systems in the Mainland and the HKSAR, the subject is very complicated.
"Both sides are fully committed to exploring a practicable option of arrangement which may be acceptable to both the Mainland and the HKSAR, and to having it put in place as soon as possible.
"We shall need to continue our discussions.
At this stage, we cannot envisage when we would be able to conclude an agreed arrangement with the Mainland.
We hope to hold another round of discussion shortly," Mrs Ip said.

"The Legislative Council will be consulted on the proposed rendition arrangement after completion of the discussions with the Mainland authorities.
Any legislative proposal to give effect to the rendition arrangement will have to be scrutinised by the council before it is passed into law," she went on.

Apart from meeting senior officials from the Hong Kong and Macau Affairs Office of the State Council, who assisted in co-ordination of the expert discussions, Mrs Ip made courtesy calls on the Ministry of Justice and the Supreme People's Court.
She also made use of the opportunity to meet the Director of the Bureau of Entry and Exit Administration, Mr Xu Ganlu.
The Court of Final Appeal's judgment on the right of abode issue was discussed.
The Secretary for Security was accompanied on her Beijing trip by officials from the Security Bureau, the Police, the Department of Justice and the Constitutional Affairs Bureau.
She will return to Hong Kong tomorrow (Thursday).
